<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Toponymy">Toponymy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Etymology_of_London" title="Etymology of London">Etymology of London</a></div>
<p><i>London</i> is an ancient name, already attested in the first century AD, usually in the <a href="/wiki/Latinisation_of_names" title="Latinisation of names">Latinised</a> form <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a></i></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-40">[36]</a></sup> for example, handwritten Roman tablets recovered in the city originating from AD 65/70–80 include the word <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Londinio</i></span> ('in London').<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NameTablets_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-NameTablets-41">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over the years, the name has attracted many mythically based explanations. The earliest attested appears in <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth" title="Geoffrey of Monmouth">Geoffrey of Monmouth</a>'s <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Historia_Regum_Britanniae" title="Historia Regum Britanniae">Historia Regum Britanniae</a></i></span>, written around 1136.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-40">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern scientific analyses of the name must account for the origins of the different forms found in early sources: <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> (usually <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Londinium</i></span>), <a href="/wiki/Old_English" title="Old English">Old English</a> (usually <span title="Old English (ca. 450-1100)-language text"><i lang="ang">Lunden</i></span>), and <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a> (usually <span title="Welsh-language text"><i lang="cy">Llundein</i></span>), with reference to the known developments over time of sounds in those different languages. It is agreed that the name came into these languages from <a href="/wiki/Common_Brittonic" title="Common Brittonic">Common Brythonic</a>; recent work tends to reconstruct the lost Celtic form of the name as <span title="Proto-Celtic-language text">*<i lang="cel">Londonjon</i></span> or something similar. This was adapted into Latin as <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Londinium</i></span> and borrowed into Old English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-43">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>The toponymy of the Common Brythonic form is debated. Prominent was <a href="/wiki/Richard_Coates" title="Richard Coates">Richard Coates</a>' 1998 argument that it derived from pre-Celtic <a href="/wiki/Old_European_hydronymy" title="Old European hydronymy">Old European</a> *<span class="Unicode" style="white-space:nowrap;" title="Proto-Indo-European language"><span lang="ine"><i>(p)lowonida</i></span></span>, meaning "river too wide to ford". Coates suggested this was a name given to the part of the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">River Thames</a> that flows through London, from which the settlement gained the <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Britons" title="Celtic Britons">Celtic</a> form of its name, <span title="Proto-Celtic-language text">*<i lang="cel">Lowonidonjon</i></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coates_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-coates-44">[40]</a></sup> However, most work has accepted a plain Celtic origin. Recent studies favour an explanation of a Celtic derivative of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European" title="Proto-Indo-European">Proto-Indo-European</a> root *<span class="Unicode" style="white-space:nowrap;" title="Proto-Indo-European language"><span lang="ine"><i>lend<sup>h</sup>-</i></span></span> ('sink, cause to sink'), combined with the Celtic suffix <span title="Proto-Celtic-language text">*<i lang="cel">-injo-</i></span> or <span title="Proto-Celtic-language text">*<i lang="cel">-onjo-</i></span> (used to form place-names). <a href="/wiki/Peter_Schrijver" title="Peter Schrijver">Peter Schrijver</a> has specifically suggested that the name originally meant "place that floods (periodically, tidally)".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-43">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Until 1889, the name "London" applied officially only to the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>, but since then it has also referred to the <a href="/wiki/County_of_London" title="County of London">County of London</a> and to <a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">Greater London</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>In writing, "London" is occasionally <a href="/wiki/Contraction_(grammar)" title="Contraction (grammar)">contracted</a> to "LDN".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[44]</a></sup> Such usage originated in <a href="/wiki/SMS_language" title="SMS language">SMS language</a> and often appears in a social media <a href="/wiki/User_profile" title="User profile">user profile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suffix" title="Suffix">suffixing</a> an <a href="/wiki/Pseudonym" title="Pseudonym">alias</a> or handle.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_London" title="History of London">History of London</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_London" title="Timeline of London">Timeline of London</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<p>In 1993, remains of a <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> bridge were found on the south foreshore upstream from <a href="/wiki/Vauxhall_Bridge" title="Vauxhall Bridge">Vauxhall Bridge</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Denison_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-Denison-49">[45]</a></sup> This either crossed the Thames or reached a now-lost island in it. Two of the timbers were <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">radiocarbon dated</a> to 1750–1285 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Denison_49-1"><a href="#cite_note-Denison-49">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, foundations of a large timber structure, dated to 4800–4500 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[46]</a></sup> were found on the Thames's south foreshore downstream from Vauxhall Bridge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Milne_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-Milne-51">[47]</a></sup> The function of the <a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">mesolithic</a> structure is unclear. Both structures are on the south bank of the Thames, where the now-underground <a href="/wiki/River_Effra" title="River Effra">River Effra</a> flows into the Thames.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Milne_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-Milne-51">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Roman_London">Roman London</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_London,_1300.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="842" data-file-width="1080" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Map_of_London%2C_1300.svg/220px-Map_of_London%2C_1300.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Map_of_London%2C_1300.svg/330px-Map_of_London%2C_1300.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Map_of_London%2C_1300.svg/440px-Map_of_London%2C_1300.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_London,_1300.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 1300, the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City</a> was still confined within the <a href="/wiki/London_Wall" title="London Wall">Roman walls</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Despite the evidence of scattered Brythonic settlements in the area, the first major settlement was founded by the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Romans</a> about four years<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-2">[2]</a></sup> after the invasion of 43 AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roman_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-roman-52">[48]</a></sup> This only lasted until about 61 AD, when the <a href="/wiki/Iceni" title="Iceni">Iceni</a> tribe led by <a href="/wiki/Boudica" title="Boudica">Queen Boudica</a> stormed it and burnt it to the ground.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_010_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_010-53">[49]</a></sup> The next planned incarnation of <a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a> prospered, superseding <a href="/wiki/Colchester" title="Colchester">Colchester</a> as capital of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">Roman province</a> of <a href="/wiki/Britannia" title="Britannia">Britannia</a> in 100. At its height in the 2nd century, Roman London had a population of about 60,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Anglo-Saxon_and_Viking-period_London">Anglo-Saxon and Viking-period London</span></h3>
<p>With the early 5th-century collapse of Roman rule, London ceased to be a capital and the walled city of <a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a> was effectively abandoned, although <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_civilisation" title="Roman civilisation">Roman civilisation</a> continued around <a href="/wiki/St_Martin-in-the-Fields" title="St Martin-in-the-Fields">St Martin-in-the-Fields</a> until about 450.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[51]</a></sup> From about 500, an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon" title="Anglo-Saxon">Anglo-Saxon</a> settlement known as <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_London" title="Anglo-Saxon London">Lundenwic</a> developed slightly west of the old Roman city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_011_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_011-56">[52]</a></sup> By about 680 the city had become a major port again, but there is little evidence of large-scale production. From the 820s repeated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viking" title="Viking">Viking</a> assaults brought decline. Three are recorded; those in 851 and 886 succeeded, while the last, in 994, was rebuffed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Viking_Attacks_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Viking_Attacks-57">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Siege_of_London_(MS_1168).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="488" data-file-width="320" decoding="async" height="259" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg/170px-Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg/255px-Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d3/Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Siege_of_London_(MS_1168).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/House_of_Lancaster" title="House of Lancaster">Lancastrian</a> siege of London in 1471 is attacked by a <a href="/wiki/House_of_York" title="House of York">Yorkist</a> sally.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Vikings</a> applied <a href="/wiki/Danelaw" title="Danelaw">Danelaw</a> over much of eastern and northern England, its boundary running roughly from London to <a href="/wiki/Chester" title="Chester">Chester</a> as an area of political and geographical control imposed by the <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Viking</a> incursions formally agreed by the <a href="/wiki/Danes" title="Danes">Danish</a> <a href="/wiki/Warlord" title="Warlord">warlord</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guthrum" title="Guthrum">Guthrum</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_West_Saxons" title="Kingdom of the West Saxons">West Saxon</a> king <a href="/wiki/Alfred_the_Great" title="Alfred the Great">Alfred the Great</a> in 886. The <i><a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_Chronicle" title="Anglo-Saxon Chronicle">Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</a></i> records that Alfred "refounded" London in 886. Archaeological research shows this involved abandonment of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lundenwic" title="Lundenwic">Lundenwic</a> and a revival of life and trade within the old Roman walls. London then grew slowly until a dramatic increase in about 950.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blackwell_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-blackwell-58">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the 11th century, London was clearly the largest town in England. <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>, rebuilt in <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_architecture" title="Romanesque architecture">Romanesque</a> style by King <a href="/wiki/Edward_the_Confessor" title="Edward the Confessor">Edward the Confessor</a>, was one of the grandest churches in Europe. <a href="/wiki/Winchester" title="Winchester">Winchester</a> had been the capital of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Anglo-Saxon_England" title="History of Anglo-Saxon England">Anglo-Saxon England</a>, but from this time London became the main forum for foreign traders and the base for defence in time of war. In the view of <a href="/wiki/Frank_Stenton" title="Frank Stenton">Frank Stenton</a>: "It had the resources, and it was rapidly developing the dignity and the political self-consciousness appropriate to a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_capital" title="National capital">national capital</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto,_1749.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="984" data-file-width="1008" decoding="async" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg/220px-Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg/330px-Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg/440px-Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto,_1749.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>, as seen in this painting (by <a href="/wiki/Canaletto" title="Canaletto">Canaletto</a>, 1749), is a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> and one of London's oldest and most important buildings.</div></div></div>
<p>After winning the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings" title="Battle of Hastings">Battle of Hastings</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_the_Conqueror" title="William the Conqueror">William, Duke of Normandy</a> was crowned <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_of_England" title="King of England">King of England</a> in newly completed <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> on Christmas Day 1066.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_015_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_015-61">[57]</a></sup> William built the <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a>, the first of many such in England rebuilt in stone in the south-eastern corner of the city, to intimidate the inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_016_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_016-62">[58]</a></sup> In 1097, <a href="/wiki/William_II_of_England" title="William II of England">William II</a> began building <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Westminster_Hall" title="Westminster Hall">Westminster Hall</a>, close by the abbey of the same name. It became the basis of a new <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_017_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_017-63">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_018_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_018-64">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 12th century, the institutions of central government, which had hitherto followed the royal English court around the country, grew in size and sophistication and became increasingly fixed, for most purposes at <a href="/wiki/Westminster" title="Westminster">Westminster</a>, although the royal treasury, having been moved from <a href="/wiki/Winchester" title="Winchester">Winchester</a>, came to rest in the <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower</a>. While the <a href="/wiki/Westminster" title="Westminster">City of Westminster</a> developed into a true governmental capital, its distinct neighbour, the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>, remained England's largest city and principal commercial centre and flourished under its own unique administration, the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation" title="City of London Corporation">Corporation of London</a>. In 1100, its population was some 18,000; by 1300 it had grown to nearly 100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_019_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_019-65">[61]</a></sup> Disaster struck in the form of the <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a> in the mid-14th century, when London lost nearly a third of its population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup> London was the focus of the <a href="/wiki/Peasants%27_Revolt" title="Peasants' Revolt">Peasants' Revolt</a> in 1381.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_020_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_020-67">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>London was also a centre of England's <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_England_(1066%E2%80%931290)" title="History of the Jews in England (1066–1290)">Jewish population</a> before their <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Expulsion" title="Edict of Expulsion">expulsion</a> by <a href="/wiki/Edward_I_of_England" title="Edward I of England">Edward I</a> in 1290. Violence against Jews occurred in 1190, when it was rumoured that the new king had ordered their massacre after they had presented themselves at his coronation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jacobs_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jacobs-68">[64]</a></sup> In 1264 during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Barons%27_War" title="Second Barons' War">Second Barons' War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Simon_de_Montfort,_6th_Earl_of_Leicester" title="Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester">Simon de Montfort</a>'s rebels killed 500 Jews while attempting to seize records of debts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mundill2010_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mundill2010-69">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern">Early modern</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3760" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg/220px-London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg/330px-London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg/440px-London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of London in 1593. There is only one bridge across the Thames, but parts of Southwark on the south bank of the river have been developed.</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Tudor_period" title="Tudor period">Tudor period</a> the <a href="/wiki/English_Reformation" title="English Reformation">Reformation</a> produced a gradual shift to <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a>. Much of London property passed from church to private ownership, which accelerated trade and business in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pevsner_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-pevsner-70">[66]</a></sup> In 1475, the <a href="/wiki/Hanseatic_League" title="Hanseatic League">Hanseatic League</a> set up a main trading base (<i><a href="/wiki/Kontor" title="Kontor">kontor</a></i>) of England in London, called the <i>Stalhof</i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Steelyard" title="Steelyard">Steelyard</a></i>. It remained until 1853, when the Hanseatic cities of <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck" title="Lübeck">Lübeck</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bremen" title="Bremen">Bremen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> sold the property to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Eastern_Railway,_UK" title="South Eastern Railway, UK">South Eastern Railway</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB-71">[67]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Woollen" title="Woollen">Woollen</a> cloth was shipped undyed and undressed from 14th/15th century London to the nearby shores of the <a href="/wiki/Low_Countries" title="Low Countries">Low Countries</a>, where it was considered indispensable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yet English maritime enterprise hardly reached beyond the seas of <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_Europe" title="Northwestern Europe">north-west Europe</a>. The commercial route to Italy and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> was normally through <a href="/wiki/Antwerp" title="Antwerp">Antwerp</a> and over the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a>; any ships passing through the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar" title="Strait of Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a> to or from England were likely to be Italian or <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa" title="Republic of Ragusa">Ragusan</a>. The reopening of the Netherlands to English shipping in January 1565 spurred a burst of commercial activity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[69]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London" title="Royal Exchange, London">Royal Exchange</a> was founded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[70]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mercantilism" title="Mercantilism">Mercantilism</a> grew and monopoly traders such as the <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> were founded as trade expanded to the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>. London became the main <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> port, with migrants arriving from England and abroad. The population rose from about 50,000 in 1530 to about 225,000 in 1605.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pevsner_70-1"><a href="#cite_note-pevsner-70">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 16th century, <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> and his contemporaries lived in London during <a href="/wiki/English_Renaissance_theatre" title="English Renaissance theatre">English Renaissance theatre</a>. Shakespeare's <a href="/wiki/Globe_Theatre" title="Globe Theatre">Globe Theatre</a> was constructed in 1599 in <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Southwark" title="London Borough of Southwark">Southwark</a>. Stage performances came to a halt in London when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puritan" title="Puritan">Puritan</a> authorities <a href="/wiki/London_theatre_closure_1642" title="London theatre closure 1642">shut down the theatres</a> in the 1640s and 1650s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[71]</a></sup> The ban on theatre was lifted during <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Restoration" title="Stuart Restoration">the Restoration</a> in 1660, and London's oldest operating theatre, <a href="/wiki/Theatre_Royal,_Drury_Lane" title="Theatre Royal, Drury Lane">Drury Lane</a>, opened in 1663 in what is now the <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End</a> theatre district.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the end of the Tudor period in 1603, London was still compact. There was an assassination attempt on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_I_of_England" title="James I of England">James I</a> in Westminster, in the <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder_Plot" title="Gunpowder Plot">Gunpowder Plot</a> of 5 November 1605.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_023_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_023-77">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vertue%27s_1738_plan_of_the_London_Lines_of_Communication.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2455" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vertue%27s_1738_plan_of_the_London_Lines_of_Communication.jpg/220px-Vertue%27s_1738_plan_of_the_London_Lines_of_Communication.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vertue%27s_1738_plan_of_the_London_Lines_of_Communication.jpg/330px-Vertue%27s_1738_plan_of_the_London_Lines_of_Communication.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vertue%27s_1738_plan_of_the_London_Lines_of_Communication.jpg/440px-Vertue%27s_1738_plan_of_the_London_Lines_of_Communication.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vertue%27s_1738_plan_of_the_London_Lines_of_Communication.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Defensive <a href="/wiki/Lines_of_Communication_(London)" title="Lines of Communication (London)">Lines of Communication</a>, planned during the <a href="/wiki/English_Civil_War" title="English Civil War">English Civil War</a>, c. 1643, surrounded the City, Westminster, Southwark, Lambeth and related areas (Vertue, 1738).</div></div></div>
<p>In 1637, the government of <a href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_England" title="Charles I of England">Charles I</a> attempted to reform administration in the London area. This called for the Corporation of the city to extend its jurisdiction and administration over expanding areas around the city. Fearing an attempt by the Crown to diminish the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liberties_of_London" title="Liberties of London">Liberties of London</a>, coupled with a lack of interest in administering these additional areas or concern by city guilds of having to share power, caused the Corporation's "The Great Refusal", a decision which largely continues to account for the unique governmental status of the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the English Civil War the majority of Londoners supported the <a href="/wiki/Roundhead" title="Roundhead">Parliamentary</a> cause. After an initial advance by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cavaliers" title="Cavaliers">Royalists</a> in 1642, culminating in the battles of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Brentford_(1642)" title="Battle of Brentford (1642)">Brentford</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Turnham_Green" title="Battle of Turnham Green">Turnham Green</a>, London was surrounded by a defensive perimeter wall known as the <a href="/wiki/Lines_of_Communication_(London)" title="Lines of Communication (London)">Lines of Communication</a>. The lines were built by up to 20,000 people, and were completed in under two months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[75]</a></sup>
The fortifications failed their only test when the <a href="/wiki/New_Model_Army" title="New Model Army">New Model Army</a> entered London in 1647,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[76]</a></sup> and they were levelled by Parliament the same year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>London was <a href="/wiki/Bubonic_plague" title="Bubonic plague">plagued</a> by disease in the early 17th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_024_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_024-82">[78]</a></sup> culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Plague_of_London" title="Great Plague of London">Great Plague</a> of 1665–1666, which killed up to 100,000 people, or a fifth of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_025_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_025-83">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Great_Fire_London.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3189" data-file-width="5477" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Great_Fire_London.jpg/220px-Great_Fire_London.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Great_Fire_London.jpg/330px-Great_Fire_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Great_Fire_London.jpg/440px-Great_Fire_London.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Great_Fire_London.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire of London</a> destroyed many parts of the city in 1666.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire of London</a> broke out in 1666 in Pudding Lane in the city and quickly swept through the wooden buildings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Samuel_Pepys'_Diary_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-Samuel_Pepys'_Diary-84">[80]</a></sup> Rebuilding took over ten years and was supervised by polymath <a href="/wiki/Robert_Hooke" title="Robert Hooke">Robert Hooke</a> as surveyor for the City of London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_026_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_026-85">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_027_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_027-86">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_028_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_028-87">[83]</a></sup> In 1708 <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Wren" title="Christopher Wren">Christopher Wren</a>'s masterpiece, <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul's Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a>, was completed. During the <a href="/wiki/Georgian_era" title="Georgian era">Georgian era</a>, new districts such as <a href="/wiki/Mayfair" title="Mayfair">Mayfair</a> were formed in the west; new bridges over the Thames encouraged development in <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South London</a>. In the east, the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London" title="Port of London">Port of London</a> expanded downstream. London's development as an international <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a> matured for much of the 18th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finance_Hub_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Finance_Hub-88">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1762, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/George_III_of_Great_Britain" title="George III of Great Britain">George III</a> acquired <a href="/wiki/Buckingham_Palace" title="Buckingham Palace">Buckingham House</a>, which was enlarged over the next 75 years. During the 18th century, London was said to be dogged by crime,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[85]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Bow_Street_Runners" title="Bow Street Runners">Bow Street Runners</a> were established in 1750 as a professional police force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[86]</a></sup> A total of more than 200 offences were punishable by death,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[87]</a></sup> including petty theft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[88]</a></sup> Epidemics during the 1720s and 30s saw most children born in the city die before reaching their fifth birthday.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Coffeehouse" title="Coffeehouse">Coffee-houses</a> became a popular place to debate ideas, as growing <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">literacy</a> and development of the <a href="/wiki/Printing_press" title="Printing press">printing press</a> made news widely available, with <a href="/wiki/Fleet_Street" title="Fleet Street">Fleet Street</a> becoming the centre of the British press. The invasion of Amsterdam by Napoleonic armies led many financiers to relocate to London and the first London international issue was arranged in 1817. Around the same time, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> became the world's leading war fleet, acting as a major deterrent to potential economic adversaries. The repeal of the <a href="/wiki/Corn_Laws" title="Corn Laws">Corn Laws</a> in 1846 was specifically aimed at weakening Dutch economic power. London then overtook Amsterdam as the leading international financial centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-94">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[91]</a></sup>
According to Samuel Johnson:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>You find no man, at all intellectual, who is willing to leave London. No, Sir, when a man is tired of London, he is tired of life; for there is in London all that life can afford.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/Samuel_Johnson" title="Samuel Johnson">Samuel Johnson</a>, 1777<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_022_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_022-96">[92]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Late_modern_and_contemporary">Late modern and contemporary</span></h3>
<p>With the onset of the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> in Britain, an unprecedented growth in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urbanisation" title="Urbanisation">urbanisation</a> took place, and the number of <a href="/wiki/High_Street" title="High Street">High Streets</a> (the primary street for retail in Britain) rapidly grew.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sales-97">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[94]</a></sup> London was the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_throughout_history" title="List of largest cities throughout history">largest city</a> from about 1831 to 1925,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_030_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_030-99">[95]</a></sup> with a population density of 325 per hectare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bertaud_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bertaud-100">[96]</a></sup> In addition to the growing number of stores selling goods such as <a href="/wiki/Harding,_Howell_%26_Co." title="Harding, Howell &amp; Co.">Harding, Howell &amp; Co.</a> on <a href="/wiki/Pall_Mall,_London" title="Pall Mall, London">Pall Mall</a>—a contender for the first <a href="/wiki/Department_store" title="Department store">department store</a>—the streets had scores of <a href="/wiki/Hawker_(trade)" title="Hawker (trade)">street sellers</a> loudly advertising their goods and services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales_97-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sales-97">[93]</a></sup> London's overcrowded conditions led to <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a> epidemics,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[97]</a></sup> claiming 14,000 lives in 1848, and 6,000 in 1866.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[98]</a></sup> Rising <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">traffic congestion</a> led to the creation of the world's first local urban rail network. The <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Board_of_Works" title="Metropolitan Board of Works">Metropolitan Board of Works</a> oversaw infrastructure expansion in the capital and some surrounding counties; it was abolished in 1889 when the <a href="/wiki/London_County_Council" title="London County Council">London County Council</a> was created out of county areas surrounding the capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the early years of the 20th century onwards, <a href="/wiki/Tea_in_the_United_Kingdom#Tea_rooms" title="Tea in the United Kingdom">teashops</a> were found on High Streets across London and the rest of Britain, with <a href="/wiki/J._Lyons_and_Co." title="J. Lyons and Co.">Lyons</a>, who opened the first of their <a href="/wiki/Chain_store" title="Chain store">chain</a> of teashops in <a href="/wiki/Piccadilly" title="Piccadilly">Piccadilly</a> in 1894, leading the way.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[100]</a></sup> The tearooms, such as the <a href="/wiki/Criterion_Restaurant" title="Criterion Restaurant">Criterion</a> in Piccadilly, became a popular meeting place for women from the suffrage movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[101]</a></sup> The city was the target of many attacks during the <a href="/wiki/Suffragette_bombing_and_arson_campaign" title="Suffragette bombing and arson campaign">suffragette bombing and arson campaign</a>, between 1912 and 1914, which saw historic landmarks such as <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> and <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul's Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a> bombed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="859" data-file-width="1247" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/220px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/330px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/440px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">British volunteer recruits in London, August 1914, during <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1406" data-file-width="1968" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg/220px-LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg/330px-LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg/440px-LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">A bombed-out London street during <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">the Blitz</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><span class="anchor" id="German_air_attacks"></span>London was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_strategic_bombing_during_World_War_I" title="German strategic bombing during World War I">bombed by the Germans</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War">First World War</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[103]</a></sup> and during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">Second World War</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">the Blitz</a> and other bombings by the German <i><a href="/wiki/Luftwaffe" title="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a></i> killed over 30,000 Londoners, destroying large tracts of housing and other buildings across the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics" title="1948 Summer Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a> were held at the original <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_(1923)" title="Wembley Stadium (1923)">Wembley Stadium</a>, while London was still recovering from the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[105]</a></sup> From the 1940s, London became home to many immigrants, primarily from <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a> countries such as Jamaica, India, Bangladesh and Pakistan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[106]</a></sup> making London one of the most diverse cities in the world. In 1951, the <a href="/wiki/Festival_of_Britain" title="Festival of Britain">Festival of Britain</a> was held on the <a href="/wiki/South_Bank" title="South Bank">South Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[107]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Smog" title="Great Smog">Great Smog</a> of 1952 led to the <a href="/wiki/Clean_Air_Act_1956" title="Clean Air Act 1956">Clean Air Act 1956</a>, which ended the "<a href="/wiki/Pea_soup_fog" title="Pea soup fog">pea soup fogs</a>" for which London had been notorious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>Starting mainly in the mid-1960s, London became a centre for worldwide <a href="/wiki/Youth_culture" title="Youth culture">youth culture</a>, exemplified by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Swinging_London" title="Swinging London">Swinging London</a> sub-culture<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[109]</a></sup> associated with the <a href="/wiki/King%27s_Road" title="King's Road">King's Road</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chelsea,_London" title="Chelsea, London">Chelsea</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[110]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Carnaby_Street" title="Carnaby Street">Carnaby Street</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[111]</a></sup> The role of trendsetter revived in the <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk</a> era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[112]</a></sup> In 1965 London's political boundaries were expanded in response to the growth of the urban area and a new <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Council" title="Greater London Council">Greater London Council</a> was created.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[113]</a></sup> During <a href="/wiki/The_Troubles" title="The Troubles">The Troubles</a> in Northern Ireland, London was hit from 1973 by bomb attacks by the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Irish_Republican_Army" title="Provisional Irish Republican Army">Provisional Irish Republican Army</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[114]</a></sup> These attacks lasted for two decades, starting with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_Bailey_bombing" title="Old Bailey bombing">Old Bailey bombing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[116]</a></sup> Racial inequality was highlighted by the <a href="/wiki/1981_Brixton_riot" title="1981 Brixton riot">1981 Brixton riot</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>Greater London's population declined in the decades after the Second World War, from an estimated peak of 8.6 million in 1939 to around 6.8 million in the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[118]</a></sup> The principal ports for London moved downstream to <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Felixstowe" title="Port of Felixstowe">Felixstowe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Tilbury" title="Port of Tilbury">Tilbury</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/London_Docklands" title="London Docklands">London Docklands</a> area becoming a focus for regeneration, including the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a> development. This was born out of London's increasing role as an international financial centre in the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[119]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Thames_Barrier" title="Thames Barrier">Thames Barrier</a> was completed in the 1980s to protect London against tidal surges from the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Greater London Council was abolished in 1986, leaving London with no central administration until 2000 and the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority" title="Greater London Authority">Greater London Authority</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[121]</a></sup> To mark the 21st century, the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Dome" title="Millennium Dome">Millennium Dome</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Eye" title="London Eye">London Eye</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Millennium_Bridge_(London)" title="Millennium Bridge (London)">Millennium Bridge</a> were constructed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[122]</a></sup> On 6 July 2005 London was awarded the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>, as the first city to stage the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a> three times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[123]</a></sup> On 7 July 2005, three <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a> trains and a double-decker bus were bombed in a <a href="/wiki/7_July_2005_London_bombings" title="7 July 2005 London bombings">series of terrorist attacks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_031_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_031-128">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2008, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> named London alongside New York City and Hong Kong as <a href="/wiki/Nylonkong" title="Nylonkong">Nylonkong</a>, hailing them as the world's three most influential <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_cities" title="Global cities">global cities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[125]</a></sup> In January 2015, Greater London's population was estimated to be 8.63 million, its highest since 1939.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gla-pop-2015_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-gla-pop-2015-130">[126]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/2016_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum">Brexit referendum</a> in 2016, the UK as a whole decided to leave the European Union, but most London constituencies voted for remaining.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administration">Administration</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Local_government">Local government</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_London" title="Local government in London">Local government in London</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_local_government_in_London" title="History of local government in London">History of local government in London</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_heads_of_London_government" title="List of heads of London government">List of heads of London government</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_The_City_of_London.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="505" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Coat_of_Arms_of_The_City_of_London.svg/220px-Coat_of_Arms_of_The_City_of_London.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Coat_of_Arms_of_The_City_of_London.svg/330px-Coat_of_Arms_of_The_City_of_London.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Coat_of_Arms_of_The_City_of_London.svg/440px-Coat_of_Arms_of_The_City_of_London.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_The_City_of_London.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_the_City_of_London" title="Coat of arms of the City of London">Arms of the Corporation of the City of London</a>: <i>Argent, a cross gules in the first quarter a sword in pale point upwards of the last</i>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supporters_(heraldry)" title="Supporters (heraldry)">Supporters</a>: <i>Two dragons with wings elevated and addorsed argent on each wing a cross gules</i>; <a href="/wiki/Crest_(heraldry)" title="Crest (heraldry)">Crest</a>: <i>On a dragon's wing displayed <a href="/wiki/Dexter_and_sinister" title="Dexter and sinister">sinister</a> a cross gules</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[128]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The administration of London is formed of two tiers: a citywide, strategic tier and a local tier. Citywide administration is coordinated by the <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority" title="Greater London Authority">Greater London Authority</a> (GLA), while local administration is carried out by 33 smaller authorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_032_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_032-133">[129]</a></sup> The GLA consists of two elected components: the <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_London" title="Mayor of London">mayor of London</a>, who has <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Executive_powers" title="Executive powers">executive powers</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/London_Assembly" title="London Assembly">London Assembly</a>, which scrutinises the mayor's decisions and can accept or reject the mayor's budget proposals each year.
</p><p>The headquarters of the GLA is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_Hall,_Newham" title="City Hall, Newham">City Hall</a>, Newham. The mayor since 2016 has been <a href="/wiki/Sadiq_Khan" title="Sadiq Khan">Sadiq Khan</a>, the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> mayor of a major Western capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[131]</a></sup> The mayor's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Statutory_planning" title="Statutory planning">statutory planning</a> strategy is published as the <a href="/wiki/London_Plan" title="London Plan">London Plan</a>, which was most recently revised in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_plan_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_plan-136">[132]</a></sup> The local authorities are the councils of the 32 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_borough" title="London borough">London boroughs</a> and the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation" title="City of London Corporation">City of London Corporation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_035_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_035-137">[133]</a></sup> They are responsible for most local services, such as local planning, schools, <a href="/wiki/Social_work" title="Social work">social services</a>, local roads and refuse collection. Certain functions, such as <a href="/wiki/Waste_disposal_authorities_in_London" title="Waste disposal authorities in London">waste management</a>, are provided through joint arrangements. In 2009–2010 the combined revenue expenditure by London councils and the GLA amounted to just over £22 billion (£14.7 billion for the boroughs and £7.4 billion for the GLA).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/London_Fire_Brigade" title="London Fire Brigade">London Fire Brigade</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Statute" title="Statute">statutory</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fire_service_in_the_UK" title="Fire service in the UK">fire and rescue service</a> for Greater London, run by the <a href="/wiki/London_Fire_and_Emergency_Planning_Authority" title="London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority">London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority</a>. It is the third largest fire service in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LFB_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-LFB-139">[135]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a> <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services" title="Emergency medical services">ambulance services</a> are provided by the <a href="/wiki/London_Ambulance_Service" title="London Ambulance Service">London Ambulance Service (LAS) NHS Trust</a>, the largest free-at-the-point-of-use emergency ambulance service in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LAS_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-LAS-140">[136]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Air_Ambulance" title="London Air Ambulance">London Air Ambulance</a> charity operates in conjunction with the LAS where required. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Coastguard" title="Her Majesty's Coastguard">Her Majesty's Coastguard</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_National_Lifeboat_Institution" title="Royal National Lifeboat Institution">Royal National Lifeboat Institution</a> operate on the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">River Thames</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coastguard_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coastguard-141">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lifeboat_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lifeboat-142">[138]</a></sup> which is under the jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London_Authority" title="Port of London Authority">Port of London Authority</a> from <a href="/wiki/Teddington_Lock" title="Teddington Lock">Teddington Lock</a> to the sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="National_government">National government</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1738" data-file-width="1392" decoding="async" height="237" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg/190px-10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg/285px-10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg/380px-10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="190"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/10_Downing_Street" title="10 Downing Street">10 Downing Street</a>, official  residence of the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">Prime Minister</a></div></div></div>
<p>London is the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">Government of the United Kingdom</a>. Many government departments, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">prime minister's</a> residence at <a href="/wiki/10_Downing_Street" title="10 Downing Street">10 Downing Street</a>, are based close to the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>, particularly along <a href="/wiki/Whitehall" title="Whitehall">Whitehall</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_036_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_036-144">[140]</a></sup> There are 73 members of Parliament (MPs) from London, elected from local parliamentary <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Parliamentary_constituencies_in_Greater_London" title="List of Parliamentary constituencies in Greater London">constituencies</a> in the national <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_House_of_Commons" title="British House of Commons">Parliament</a>. As of December 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=London&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 49 are from the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a>, 21 are <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservatives</a>, and three are <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Democrats_(UK)" title="Liberal Democrats (UK)">Liberal Democrats</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[141]</a></sup> The ministerial post of <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_London" title="Minister for London">minister for London</a> was created in 1994. The current Minister for London is <a href="/wiki/Paul_Scully" title="Paul Scully">Paul Scully</a> MP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Policing_and_crime">Policing and crime</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_London" title="Crime in London">Crime in London</a></div>
<p>Policing in Greater London, with the exception of the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>, is provided by the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Police" title="Metropolitan Police">Metropolitan Police</a> ("The Met"), overseen by the mayor through the <a href="/wiki/Mayor%27s_Office_for_Policing_and_Crime" title="Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime">Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime</a> (MOPAC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[144]</a></sup> The Met is also referred to as <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Yard" title="Scotland Yard">Scotland Yard</a> after the location of its original headquarters in a road called <a href="/wiki/Great_Scotland_Yard" title="Great Scotland Yard">Great Scotland Yard</a> in Whitehall. The City of London has its own police force – the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Police" title="City of London Police">City of London Police</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Policing_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Policing-149">[145]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Transport_Police" title="British Transport Police">British Transport Police</a> are responsible for police services on <a href="/wiki/National_Rail" title="National Rail">National Rail</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a>, <a href="/wiki/Docklands_Light_Railway" title="Docklands Light Railway">Docklands Light Railway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tramlink" title="Tramlink">Tramlink</a> services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BTP_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-BTP-150">[146]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_Police" title="Ministry of Defence Police">Ministry of Defence Police</a> is a special police force in London, which does not generally become involved with policing the general public.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>Crime rates vary widely across different areas of London. Crime figures are made available nationally at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Local_authority#England" title="Local authority">Local Authority</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ward_(England)" title="Ward (England)">Ward</a> level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[148]</a></sup> In 2015, there were 118 homicides, a 25.5% increase over 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[149]</a></sup> The Metropolitan Police have made detailed crime figures, broken down by category at borough and ward level, available on their website since 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Recorded crime has been rising in London, notably violent crime and murder by stabbing and other means have risen. There were 50 murders from the start of 2018 to mid April 2018. Funding cuts to police in London are likely to have contributed to this, though other factors are also involved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[152]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_London" title="Geography of London">Geography of London</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Scope">Scope</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5576" data-file-width="7368" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/220px-London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/330px-London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/440px-London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Satellite view of London in June 2018</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">London</a>, also known as Greater London, is one of nine <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_England" title="Regions of England">regions of England</a> and the top subdivision covering most of the city's metropolis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[note 4]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a> at its core once comprised the whole settlement, but as its urban area grew, the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation" title="City of London Corporation">Corporation of London</a> resisted attempts to amalgamate the City with its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suburbs" title="Suburbs">suburbs</a>, causing "London" to be defined several ways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chancery_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-chancery-158">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>Forty per cent of Greater London is covered by the <a href="/wiki/London_postal_district" title="London postal district">London post town</a>, in which 'LONDON' forms part of postal addresses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_042_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_042-159">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-map_post_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-map_post-160">[155]</a></sup> The London telephone <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code" title="Area code">area code</a> (020) covers a larger area, similar in size to Greater London, although some outer districts are excluded and some just outside included. The Greater London boundary has been <a href="/wiki/List_of_Greater_London_boundary_changes" title="List of Greater London boundary changes">aligned to the M25 motorway</a> in places.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_044_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_044-161">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>Further urban expansion is now prevented by the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Green_Belt" title="Metropolitan Green Belt">Metropolitan Green Belt</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_040_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_040-162">[157]</a></sup> although the built-up area extends beyond the boundary in places, producing a separately defined <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_London_Urban_Area" title="Greater London Urban Area">Greater London Urban Area</a>. Beyond this is the vast <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_commuter_belt" title="London commuter belt">London commuter belt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_041_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_041-163">[158]</a></sup> Greater London is split for some purposes into <a href="/wiki/Inner_London" title="Inner London">Inner London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Outer_London" title="Outer London">Outer London</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_045_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_045-164">[159]</a></sup> and by the River Thames into <a href="/wiki/North_London" title="North London">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South</a>, with an informal <a href="/wiki/Central_London" title="Central London">central London</a> area. The coordinates of the nominal centre of London, traditionally the original <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eleanor_Cross" title="Eleanor Cross">Eleanor Cross</a> at <a href="/wiki/Charing_Cross" title="Charing Cross">Charing Cross</a> near the junction of <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whitehall" title="Whitehall">Whitehall</a>, are about <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1073938472" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=London&amp;params=51_30_26_N_00_07_39_W_type:city(7,000,000)_region:GB"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">51°30′26″N</span> <span class="longitude">00°07′39″W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">51.50722°N 0.12750°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">51.50722; -0.12750</span></span></span></a></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_039_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_039-165">[160]</a></sup> Based on the centre of gravity of its map, the geographical centre of London is in the <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Lambeth" title="London Borough of Lambeth">London Borough of Lambeth</a>, 0.1 miles (150 m) to the north-east of <a href="/wiki/Lambeth_North_tube_station" title="Lambeth North tube station">Lambeth North tube station</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Status">Status</span></h3>
<p>Within London, both the City of London and the <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster" title="City of Westminster">City of Westminster</a> have <a href="/wiki/City_status_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="City status in the United Kingdom">city status</a> and both the City of London and the remainder of Greater London are <a href="/wiki/Ceremonial_counties_of_England" title="Ceremonial counties of England">counties for the purposes of lieutenancies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_049_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_049-167">[162]</a></sup> The area of <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_and_non-metropolitan_counties_of_England#Greater_London" title="Metropolitan and non-metropolitan counties of England">Greater London</a> includes areas that are part of the <a href="/wiki/Historic_counties_of_England" title="Historic counties of England">historic counties</a> of <a href="/wiki/Middlesex" title="Middlesex">Middlesex</a>, Kent, <a href="/wiki/Surrey" title="Surrey">Surrey</a>, Essex and <a href="/wiki/Hertfordshire" title="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_050_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_050-168">[163]</a></sup> London's status as the capital of England, and later the United Kingdom, has never been granted or confirmed by statute or in written form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[note 5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Its status as a capital was established by <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_convention_(political_custom)" title="Constitutional convention (political custom)">constitutional convention</a>, which means its status as <i>de facto</i> capital is a part of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Constitution of the United Kingdom">UK's uncodified constitution</a>. The capital of England was moved to London from <a href="/wiki/Winchester" title="Winchester">Winchester</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a> developed in the 12th and 13th centuries to become the permanent location of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Noble_court" title="Noble court">royal court</a>, and thus the political capital of the nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_060_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_060-173">[167]</a></sup> More recently, Greater London has been defined as a <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_England" title="Regions of England">region of England</a> and in this context is known as <i>London</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Topography">Topography</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3021" data-file-width="4388" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg/220px-London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg/330px-London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg/440px-London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>London from <a href="/wiki/Primrose_Hill" title="Primrose Hill">Primrose Hill</a></div></div></div>
<p>Greater London encompasses a total area of 611 square miles (1,583 km<sup>2</sup>) an area which had a population of 7,172,036 in 2001 and a population density of 11,760 inhabitants per square mile (4,542/km<sup>2</sup>). The extended area known as the London Metropolitan Region or the London Metropolitan Agglomeration, comprises a total area of 3,236 square miles (8,382 km<sup>2</sup>) has a population of 13,709,000 and a population density of 3,900 inhabitants per square mile (1,510/km<sup>2</sup>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern London stands on the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">Thames</a>, its primary geographical feature, a <a href="/wiki/Navigability" title="Navigability">navigable</a> river which crosses the city from the south-west to the east. The <a href="/wiki/Thames_Valley" title="Thames Valley">Thames Valley</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Floodplain" title="Floodplain">flood plain</a> surrounded by gently rolling hills including <a href="/wiki/Parliament_Hill,_London" title="Parliament Hill, London">Parliament Hill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Addington_Hills" title="Addington Hills">Addington Hills</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Primrose_Hill" title="Primrose Hill">Primrose Hill</a>. Historically London grew up at the <a href="/wiki/Lowest_bridging_point" title="Lowest bridging point">lowest bridging point</a> on the Thames. The Thames was once a much broader, shallower river with extensive <a href="/wiki/Marsh" title="Marsh">marshlands</a>; at high tide, its shores reached five times their present width.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_065_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_065-176">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian era</a> the Thames has been extensively <a href="/wiki/Thames_Embankment" title="Thames Embankment">embanked</a>, and many of its London <a href="/wiki/Tributaries_of_the_River_Thames" title="Tributaries of the River Thames">tributaries</a> now flow <a href="/wiki/Subterranean_rivers_of_London" title="Subterranean rivers of London">underground</a>. The Thames is a tidal river, and London is vulnerable to flooding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_066_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_066-177">[171]</a></sup> The threat has increased over time because of a slow but continuous rise in <a href="/wiki/Tide" title="Tide">high water</a> level caused by <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> and by the slow 'tilting' of the British Isles (up in Scotland and Northern Ireland and down in southern parts of England, Wales and Ireland) as a result of <a href="/wiki/Post-glacial_rebound" title="Post-glacial rebound">post-glacial rebound</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_067_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_067-178">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1974 a decade of work began on the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Thames_Barrier" title="Thames Barrier">Thames Barrier</a> across the Thames at <a href="/wiki/Woolwich" title="Woolwich">Woolwich</a> to deal with this threat. While the barrier is expected to function as designed until roughly 2070, concepts for its future enlargement or redesign are already being discussed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>London has had a small number of earthquakes over the years, notably those of 1750 which macroseismic information indicates had their epicentres directly under the city.  In 2018, two active faults were discovered running parallel to each other, directly under the centre of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[175]</a></sup> Furthermore, the city has been damaged at least twice (with fatalities) in the earthquakes of 1382 and 1580. Those earthquakes had their epicentres under the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[176]</a></sup> London's building code is being redrawn so that every new structure must be able to withstand an earthquake of at least 6.5 on the Richter scale.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[177]</a></sup>
</p>

<td><div style="width:1.6em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0">
<div style="height:0em;bottom:2em;width:1.6em;position:absolute;left:0;border-bottom:dotted 1px #abc;padding:0;margin:0"> </div>
<div style="background:#ace;-webkit-print-color-adjust:exact;color-adjust:exact;position:absolute;bottom:2em;left:.2em;width:1.2em;height:0.7756em;overflow:hidden"> </div>

<div style="color:red;position:absolute;bottom:7.328em; left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center"><span style="font-size:80%">39</span></div>
</div></td>
<td><div style="width:1.6em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0">

<td><div style="width:1.6em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0">

</div></td>
<td><div style="width:1.6em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0">
