<div style="color:red;position:absolute;bottom:7.552em; left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center"><span style="font-size:80%">41</span></div>
</div></td>
<td><div style="width:1.6em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0">
<div style="height:0em;bottom:2em;width:1.6em;position:absolute;left:0;border-bottom:dotted 1px #abc;padding:0;margin:0"> </div>
<div style="background:#ace;-webkit-print-color-adjust:exact;color-adjust:exact;position:absolute;bottom:2em;left:.2em;width:1.2em;height:1.141em;overflow:hidden"> </div>
<div style="color:blue;position:absolute;bottom:.5em;left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center"><span style="font-size:70%">2.2</span></div>
<div style="height:0em;bottom:8em;width:1.6em;position:absolute;left:0;border-bottom:dotted 1px #cba;padding:0;margin:0"> </div>
<div style="overflow:hidden;background:#e44;-webkit-print-color-adjust:exact;color-adjust:exact;position:absolute;left:.4em;width:0.8em;bottom:8.616em;height:1.142em;"> </div>
<div style="color:red;position:absolute;bottom:9.758em; left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center"><span style="font-size:80%">48</span></div>
<div style="color:red;position:absolute;bottom:7.116em; left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center"><span style="font-size:80%">38</span></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
<tr><td colspan="12" style="padding: 2px; text-align: left; line-height: 1.5em; color: red">Average max. and min. temperatures in °F</td></tr>
<tr><td colspan="12" style="padding: 2px; text-align: left; line-height: 1.5em; color: blue">Precipitation totals in inches</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>London has a temperate <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen</a>: <i>Cfb</i>). Rainfall records have been kept in the city since at least 1697, when records began at <a href="/wiki/Kew" title="Kew">Kew</a>. At Kew, the most rainfall in one month is 7.4 inches (189 mm) in November 1755 and the least is 0 inches (0 mm) in both December 1788 and July 1800. Mile End also had 0 inches (0 mm) in April 1893.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[178]</a></sup> The wettest year on record is 1903, with a total fall of 38.1 inches (969 mm) and the driest is 1921, with a total fall of 12.1 inches (308 mm).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[179]</a></sup> The average annual precipitation amounts to about 600 mm, which is half the annual rainfall of <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, but also lower than <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lisbon,_Portugal" title="Lisbon, Portugal">Lisbon</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sydney,_Australia" title="Sydney, Australia">Sydney, Australia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[182]</a></sup> Despite its relatively low annual precipitation, London still receives 109.6 rainy days on the 1.0 mm threshold annually. However, London is vulnerable to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Climate change in the United Kingdom">climate change in the United Kingdom</a>, and there is increasing concern among <a href="/wiki/Hydrology" title="Hydrology">hydrological</a> experts that London households may run out of water before 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>Temperature extremes in London range from 40.2 °C (104.4 °F) at Heathrow on 19 July 2022 down to −16.1 °C (3.0 °F) at Northolt on 1 January 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[185]</a></sup> Records for <a href="/wiki/Atmospheric_pressure" title="Atmospheric pressure">atmospheric pressure</a> have been kept at London since 1692. The highest pressure ever reported is 1,049.8 millibars (31.00 inHg) on 20 January 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>Summers are generally warm, sometimes hot. London's average July high is 23.5 °C (74.3 °F). On average each year, London experiences 31 days above 25 °C (77.0 °F) and 4.2 days above 30.0 °C (86.0 °F). During the <a href="/wiki/2003_European_heat_wave" title="2003 European heat wave">2003 European heat wave</a> prolonged heat led to hundreds of heat-related deaths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[187]</a></sup> There was also a previous spell of 15 consecutive days above 32.2 °C (90.0 °F) in England in 1976 which also caused many heat related deaths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[188]</a></sup> A previous temperature of 37.8 °C (100.0 °F) in August 1911 at the Greenwich station was later disregarded as non-standard.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-metoffice.gov.uk_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-metoffice.gov.uk-195">[189]</a></sup> Droughts can also, occasionally, be a problem, especially in summer, most recently in summer 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[190]</a></sup> and with much drier than average conditions prevailing from May to December.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[191]</a></sup> However, the most consecutive days without rain was 73 days in the spring of 1893.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>Winters are generally cool with little temperature variation. Heavy snow is rare but snow usually falls at least once each winter. Spring and autumn can be pleasant. As a large city, London has a considerable <a href="/wiki/Urban_heat_island" title="Urban heat island">urban heat island</a> effect,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[193]</a></sup> making the centre of London at times 5 °C (9 °F) warmer than the suburbs and outskirts. This can be seen below when comparing London Heathrow, 15 miles (24 km) west of London, with the London Weather Centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p><br/>
</p>

</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Districts">Districts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_districts_of_London" title="List of districts of London">List of districts of London</a> and <a href="/wiki/London_boroughs" title="London boroughs">London boroughs</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_(44761485915).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2652" data-file-width="4475" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/London_%2844761485915%29.jpg/290px-London_%2844761485915%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/London_%2844761485915%29.jpg/435px-London_%2844761485915%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/London_%2844761485915%29.jpg/580px-London_%2844761485915%29.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:London_(44761485915).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End theatre</a> district in 2016</div></div></div>
<p>Places within London's vast urban area are identified using district names, such as <a href="/wiki/Mayfair" title="Mayfair">Mayfair</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southwark" title="Southwark">Southwark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wembley" title="Wembley">Wembley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Whitechapel" title="Whitechapel">Whitechapel</a>. These are either informal designations, reflect the names of villages that have been absorbed by sprawl, or are superseded administrative units such as parishes or <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_boroughs_of_the_County_of_London" title="Metropolitan boroughs of the County of London">former boroughs</a>.
</p><p>Such names have remained in use through tradition, each referring to a local area with its own distinctive character, but without official boundaries. Since 1965 Greater London has been divided into 32 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_borough" title="London borough">London boroughs</a> in addition to the ancient City of London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_071_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_071-215">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_072_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_072-216">[209]</a></sup> The City of London is the main financial district,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_073_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_073-217">[210]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a> has recently developed into a new financial and commercial hub in the <a href="/wiki/London_Docklands" title="London Docklands">Docklands</a> to the east.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/West_End_of_London" title="West End of London">West End</a> is London's main entertainment and shopping district, attracting tourists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_075_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_075-218">[211]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_(London_sub_region)" title="West (London sub region)">West London</a> includes expensive residential areas where properties can sell for tens of millions of pounds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_076_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_076-219">[212]</a></sup> The average price for properties in <a href="/wiki/Royal_Borough_of_Kensington_and_Chelsea" title="Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea">Kensington and Chelsea</a> is over £2 million with a similarly high outlay in most of central London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London's_Properties_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-London's_Properties-220">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GuardAug14_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-GuardAug14-221">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/East_End_of_London" title="East End of London">East End</a> is the area closest to the original <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London" title="Port of London">Port of London</a>, known for its high immigrant population, as well as for being one of the poorest areas in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-East_End_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-East_End-222">[215]</a></sup> The surrounding <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_East_(London_sub_region)" title="North East (London sub region)">East London</a> area saw much of London's early industrial development; now, <a href="/wiki/Brownfield_land" title="Brownfield land">brownfield</a> sites throughout the area are being redeveloped as part of the <a href="/wiki/Thames_Gateway" title="Thames Gateway">Thames Gateway</a> including the <a href="/wiki/London_Riverside" title="London Riverside">London Riverside</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lower_Lea_Valley" title="Lower Lea Valley">Lower Lea Valley</a>, which was developed into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olympic_Park,_London" title="Olympic Park, London">Olympic Park</a> for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_2012_Olympic_bid" title="London 2012 Olympic bid">2012 Olympics and Paralympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-East_End_222-1"><a href="#cite_note-East_End-222">[215]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_London" title="Architecture of London">Architecture of London</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures_in_London" title="List of tallest buildings and structures in London">List of tallest buildings and structures in London</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_demolished_buildings_and_structures_in_London" title="List of demolished buildings and structures in London">List of demolished buildings and structures in London</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2636" data-file-width="4687" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg/220px-Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg/330px-Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg/440px-Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a>, a medieval castle, dating in part to 1078</div></div></div>
<p>London's buildings are too diverse to be characterised by any particular architectural style, partly because of their varying ages. Many grand houses and public buildings, such as the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a>, are constructed from <a href="/wiki/Portland_stone" title="Portland stone">Portland stone</a>. Some areas of the city, particularly those just west of the centre, are characterised by white <a href="/wiki/Stucco" title="Stucco">stucco</a> or whitewashed buildings. Few structures in central London pre-date the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire</a> of 1666, these being a few trace <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Roman</a> remains, the <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a> and a few scattered <a href="/wiki/Tudor_architecture" title="Tudor architecture">Tudor</a> survivors in the city. Further out is, for example, the <a href="/wiki/Tudor_period" title="Tudor period">Tudor-period</a> <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Court_Palace" title="Hampton Court Palace">Hampton Court Palace</a>, England's oldest surviving Tudor palace, built by Cardinal <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Wolsey" title="Thomas Wolsey">Thomas Wolsey</a> in about 1515.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buckingham_Palace_from_side,_London,_UK_-_Diliff.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5426" data-file-width="9000" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg/330px-Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg/440px-Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buckingham_Palace_from_side,_London,_UK_-_Diliff.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The east wing public façade of <a href="/wiki/Buckingham_Palace" title="Buckingham Palace">Buckingham Palace</a> was built between 1847 and 1850; it was remodelled to its present form in 1913.</div></div></div>
<p>Part of the varied architectural heritage are the 17th-century churches by <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Wren" title="Christopher Wren">Wren</a>, neoclassical financial institutions such as the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London" title="Royal Exchange, London">Royal Exchange</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>, to the early 20th century <a href="/wiki/Old_Bailey" title="Old Bailey">Old Bailey</a> and the 1960s <a href="/wiki/Barbican_Estate" title="Barbican Estate">Barbican Estate</a>.
</p><p>The 1939 <a href="/wiki/Battersea_Power_Station" title="Battersea Power Station">Battersea Power Station</a> by the river in the south-west is a local landmark, while some railway termini are excellent examples of <a href="/wiki/Victorian_architecture" title="Victorian architecture">Victorian architecture</a>, most notably <a href="/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station" title="St Pancras railway station">St. Pancras</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paddington_railway_station" title="Paddington railway station">Paddington</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_078_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_078-224">[217]</a></sup> The density of London varies, with high employment density in the <a href="/wiki/Central_London" title="Central London">central area</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a>, high residential densities in <a href="/wiki/Inner_London" title="Inner London">inner London</a>, and lower densities in <a href="/wiki/Outer_London" title="Outer London">Outer London</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg/220px-Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg/330px-Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg/440px-Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a> and its fountains, with <a href="/wiki/Nelson%27s_Column" title="Nelson's Column">Nelson's Column</a> on the right</div></div></div>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Monument" title="The Monument">The Monument</a> in the City of London provides views of the surrounding area while commemorating the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire of London</a>, which originated nearby. <a href="/wiki/Marble_Arch" title="Marble Arch">Marble Arch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wellington_Arch" title="Wellington Arch">Wellington Arch</a>, at the north and south ends of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Park_Lane_(road)" title="Park Lane (road)">Park Lane</a>, respectively, have royal connections, as do the <a href="/wiki/Albert_Memorial" title="Albert Memorial">Albert Memorial</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kensington" title="Kensington">Kensington</a>. <a href="/wiki/Nelson%27s_Column" title="Nelson's Column">Nelson's Column</a> (built to commemorate <a href="/wiki/Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson" title="Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson">Admiral Horatio Nelson</a>) is a nationally recognised monument in <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a>, one of the focal points of central London. Older buildings are mainly brick built, most commonly the yellow <a href="/wiki/London_stock_brick" title="London stock brick">London stock brick</a> or a warm orange-red variety, often decorated with carvings and white plaster <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moulding_(decorative)" title="Moulding (decorative)">mouldings</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_077_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_077-225">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:30_St_Mary_Axe_from_Leadenhall_Street.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3607" data-file-width="2631" decoding="async" height="233" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/30_St_Mary_Axe_from_Leadenhall_Street.jpg/170px-30_St_Mary_Axe_from_Leadenhall_Street.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/30_St_Mary_Axe_from_Leadenhall_Street.jpg/255px-30_St_Mary_Axe_from_Leadenhall_Street.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/30_St_Mary_Axe_from_Leadenhall_Street.jpg/340px-30_St_Mary_Axe_from_Leadenhall_Street.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:30_St_Mary_Axe_from_Leadenhall_Street.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Modern styles juxtaposed with historic styles; <a href="/wiki/30_St_Mary_Axe" title="30 St Mary Axe">30 St Mary Axe</a> (dubbed "The Gherkin")</div></div></div>
<p>In the dense areas, most of the concentration is via medium- and high-rise buildings. London's skyscrapers, such as <a href="/wiki/30_St_Mary_Axe" title="30 St Mary Axe">30 St Mary Axe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tower_42" title="Tower 42">Tower 42</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Broadgate_Tower" title="Broadgate Tower">Broadgate Tower</a> and <a href="/wiki/One_Canada_Square" title="One Canada Square">One Canada Square</a>, are mostly in the two financial districts, the City of London and <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a>. High-rise development is restricted at certain sites if it would obstruct <a href="/wiki/Protected_view" title="Protected view">protected views</a> of <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul's Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a> and other historic buildings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[219]</a></sup> This protective policy, known as 'St Paul’s Heights', has been in operation by the City of London since 1937.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[220]</a></sup> Nevertheless, there are a number of tall skyscrapers in central London (see <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tall_buildings_in_London" title="Tall buildings in London">Tall buildings in London</a>), including the 95-storey <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shard_London_Bridge" title="Shard London Bridge">Shard London Bridge</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of tallest buildings in the United Kingdom">tallest building in the United Kingdom</a>.
</p><p>Other notable modern buildings include <a href="/wiki/The_Scalpel" title="The Scalpel">The Scalpel</a>, originally a nickname coined by the <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i> due to its distinctive angular design but subsequently designated as its official name,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[221]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/20_Fenchurch_Street" title="20 Fenchurch Street">20 Fenchurch Street</a>, dubbed "The Walkie-Talkie" because of its distinctive shape that resembles a <a href="/wiki/Two-way_radio" title="Two-way radio">two-way radio</a> handset,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[222]</a></sup> the former <a href="/wiki/City_Hall,_London_(Southwark)" title="City Hall, London (Southwark)">City Hall</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southwark" title="Southwark">Southwark</a> with its distinctive oval shape,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_079_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_079-230">[223]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BBC_Broadcasting_House" title="BBC Broadcasting House">BBC Broadcasting House</a> plus the <a href="/wiki/Postmodernism" title="Postmodernism">Postmodernist</a> <a href="/wiki/British_Library" title="British Library">British Library</a> in <a href="/wiki/Somers_Town,_London" title="Somers Town, London">Somers Town</a>/<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kings_Cross,_London" title="Kings Cross, London">Kings Cross</a> and <a href="/wiki/No_1_Poultry" title="No 1 Poultry">No 1 Poultry</a> by <a href="/wiki/James_Stirling_(architect)" title="James Stirling (architect)">James Stirling</a>. What was formerly the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Dome" title="Millennium Dome">Millennium Dome</a>, by the Thames to the east of Canary Wharf, is now an entertainment venue called <a href="/wiki/The_O2_Arena" title="The O2 Arena">the O<sub>2</sub> Arena</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_(cropped).jpg" title="The Houses of Parliament and Elizabeth Tower (Big Ben) on the right foreground, the London Eye on the left foreground and The Shard with Canary Wharf in the background; seen in September 2014"><img alt="" data-file-height="2926" data-file-width="7888" decoding="async" height="371" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg/1000px-Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg/1500px-Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg/2000px-Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_(cropped).jpg" title="File:Palace of Westminster from the dome on Methodist Central Hall (cropped).jpg"> </a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Houses_of_Parliament" title="Houses of Parliament">Houses of Parliament</a> and <a href="/wiki/Big_Ben" title="Big Ben">Elizabeth Tower</a> (Big Ben) on the right foreground, the <a href="/wiki/London_Eye" title="London Eye">London Eye</a> on the left foreground and <a href="/wiki/The_Shard" title="The Shard">The Shard</a> with <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a> in the background; seen in September 2014</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Natural_history">Natural history</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/London_Natural_History_Society" title="London Natural History Society">London Natural History Society</a> suggests that London is "one of the World's Greenest Cities" with more than 40 per cent green space or open water. They indicate that 2000 species of flowering plant have been found growing there and that the <a href="/wiki/Tideway" title="Tideway">tidal Thames</a> supports 120 species of fish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[225]</a></sup> They also state that over 60 species of bird nest in <a href="/wiki/Central_London" title="Central London">central London</a> and that their members have recorded 47 species of butterfly, 1173 moths and more than 270 kinds of spider around London. London's <a href="/wiki/Wetland" title="Wetland">wetland</a> areas support nationally important populations of many water birds. London has 38 <a href="/wiki/List_of_Sites_of_Special_Scientific_Interest_in_Greater_London" title="List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Greater London">Sites of Special Scientific Interest</a> (SSSIs), two <a href="/wiki/National_nature_reserve_(United_Kingdom)" title="National nature reserve (United Kingdom)">national nature reserves</a> and 76 <a href="/wiki/List_of_local_nature_reserves_in_Greater_London" title="List of local nature reserves in Greater London">local nature reserves</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amphibians" title="Amphibians">Amphibians</a> are common in the capital, including <a href="/wiki/Smooth_newt" title="Smooth newt">smooth newts</a> living by the <a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Common_frog" title="Common frog">common frogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_toad" title="Common toad">common toads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palmate_newt" title="Palmate newt">palmate newts</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_crested_newt" title="Great crested newt">great crested newts</a>. On the other hand, native reptiles such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slowworm" title="Slowworm">slowworms</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_lizard" title="Common lizard">common lizards</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barred_grass_snake" title="Barred grass snake">barred grass snakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vipera_berus" title="Vipera berus">adders</a>, are mostly only seen in <a href="/wiki/Outer_London" title="Outer London">Outer London</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[227]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1086" data-file-width="967" decoding="async" height="247" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg/220px-Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg/330px-Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg/440px-Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A fox on Ayres Street, <a href="/wiki/Southwark" title="Southwark">Southwark</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South London</a></div></div></div>
<p>Among other inhabitants of London are 10,000 <a href="/wiki/Red_fox" title="Red fox">red foxes</a>, so that there are now 16 foxes for every square mile (6 per square kilometre) of London. These urban foxes are noticeably bolder than their country cousins, sharing the pavement with pedestrians and raising cubs in people's backyards. Foxes have even sneaked into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Houses_of_Parliament" title="Houses of Parliament">Houses of Parliament</a>, where one was found asleep on a filing cabinet. Another broke into the grounds of <a href="/wiki/Buckingham_Palace" title="Buckingham Palace">Buckingham Palace</a>, reportedly killing some of Queen Elizabeth II's prized <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pink_flamingo" title="Pink flamingo">pink flamingos</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[228]</a></sup> Generally, however, foxes and city folk appear to get along. A survey in 2001 by the London-based <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mammal_Society" title="Mammal Society">Mammal Society</a> found that 80 per cent of 3,779 respondents who volunteered to keep a diary of garden mammal visits liked having them around. This sample cannot be taken to represent Londoners as a whole.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mammalreport_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-mammalreport-236">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other mammals found in <a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">Greater London</a> are <a href="/wiki/European_hedgehog" title="European hedgehog">hedgehog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_rat" title="Brown rat">brown rat</a>, mice, <a href="/wiki/European_rabbit" title="European rabbit">rabbit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shrew" title="Shrew">shrew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vole" title="Vole">vole</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grey_squirrel" title="Grey squirrel">grey squirrel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[231]</a></sup> In wilder areas of Outer London, such as <a href="/wiki/Epping_Forest" title="Epping Forest">Epping Forest</a>, a wide variety of mammals are found, including <a href="/wiki/European_hare" title="European hare">European hare</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_badger" title="European badger">badger</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Field_vole" title="Field vole">field</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bank_vole" title="Bank vole">bank</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_water_vole" title="European water vole">water vole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wood_mouse" title="Wood mouse">wood mouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yellow-necked_mouse" title="Yellow-necked mouse">yellow-necked mouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_mole" title="European mole">mole</a>, shrew, and <a href="/wiki/Least_weasel" title="Least weasel">weasel</a>, in addition to red fox, grey squirrel and hedgehog. A dead <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_otter" title="Eurasian otter">otter</a> was found at The Highway, in <a href="/wiki/Wapping" title="Wapping">Wapping</a>, about a mile from the <a href="/wiki/Tower_Bridge" title="Tower Bridge">Tower Bridge</a>, which would suggest that they have begun to move back after being absent a hundred years from the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[232]</a></sup> Ten of England's eighteen species of bats have been recorded in Epping Forest: <a href="/wiki/Soprano_pipistrelle" title="Soprano pipistrelle">soprano</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nathusius%27_pipistrelle" title="Nathusius' pipistrelle">Nathusius'</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_pipistrelle" title="Common pipistrelle">common pipistrelles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_noctule" title="Common noctule">common noctule</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Serotine" title="Serotine">serotine</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barbastelle" title="Barbastelle">barbastelle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daubenton%27s_bat" title="Daubenton's bat">Daubenton's</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_long-eared_bat" title="Brown long-eared bat">brown long-eared</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natterer%27s_bat" title="Natterer's bat">Natterer's</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leisler%27s_bat" title="Leisler's bat">Leisler's</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[233]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the strange sights in London have been a whale in the Thames,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[234]</a></sup> while the BBC Two programme <i>Natural World: Unnatural History of London</i> shows <a href="/wiki/Feral_pigeon" title="Feral pigeon">feral pigeons</a> using the <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a> to get around the city, a <a href="/wiki/Pinniped" title="Pinniped">seal</a> that takes fish from <a href="/wiki/Fishmonger" title="Fishmonger">fishmongers</a> outside <a href="/wiki/Billingsgate_Fish_Market" title="Billingsgate Fish Market">Billingsgate Fish Market</a>, and foxes that will "sit" if given sausages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[235]</a></sup>
</p><p>Herds of <a href="/wiki/Red_deer" title="Red deer">red</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fallow_deer" title="Fallow deer">fallow deer</a> also roam freely within much of <a href="/wiki/Richmond_Park" title="Richmond Park">Richmond</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bushy_Park" title="Bushy Park">Bushy Park</a>. A cull takes place each November and February to ensure numbers can be sustained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Deer_cull_begins_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-Deer_cull_begins-243">[236]</a></sup> Epping Forest is also known for its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fallow_deer" title="Fallow deer">fallow deer</a>, which can frequently be seen in herds to the north of the Forest. A rare population of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Melanistic" title="Melanistic">melanistic</a>, black fallow deer is also maintained at the Deer Sanctuary near <a href="/wiki/Theydon_Bois" title="Theydon Bois">Theydon Bois</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reeve%27s_muntjac" title="Reeve's muntjac">Muntjac deer</a>, which escaped from deer parks at the turn of the 20th century, are also found in the forest. While Londoners are accustomed to wildlife such as birds and foxes sharing the city, more recently urban deer have started becoming a regular feature, and whole herds of fallow deer come into residential areas at night to take advantage of London's green spaces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[238]</a></sup>
</p>

<td><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/France" title="France"><img alt="France" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/35px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/45px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/French_migration_to_the_United_Kingdom" title="French migration to the United Kingdom">France</a></td>
<td>66,654
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Greater_London_population_density_map,_2011_census.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3178" data-file-width="3896" decoding="async" height="237" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png/290px-Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png/435px-Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png/580px-Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Greater_London_population_density_map,_2011_census.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population density map</div></div></div>
<p>The 2011 census recorded that 2,998,264 people or 36.7% of London's population were <a href="/wiki/Foreign-born_population_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Foreign-born population of the United Kingdom">foreign-born</a> making it the city with the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_born#Cities_with_largest_foreign_born_populations" title="Foreign born">second largest immigrant population</a> after New York, in terms of absolute numbers. About 69% of children born in London in 2015 had at least one parent who was born abroad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[240]</a></sup> The table to the right shows the commonest countries of birth of London residents. Note that some of the German-born population, in 18th position, are British citizens from birth born to parents serving in the <a href="/wiki/British_Armed_Forces" title="British Armed Forces">British Armed Forces</a> in Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[241]</a></sup>
</p><p>Increasing industrialisation swelled London's population throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries, and for some time in the late 19th and early 20th centuries it was the most populous city in the world. It peaked at 8,615,245 in 1939, just before the outbreak of the Second World War, but had declined to 7,192,091 by the 2001 Census. However, the population then grew by just over a million between the 2001 and 2011 Censuses, to reach 8,173,941 in the latter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[242]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, London's continuous urban area extends beyond Greater London and numbered 9,787,426 people in 2011,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-urbanpopulation_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-urbanpopulation-34">[31]</a></sup> while its wider <a href="/wiki/London_metropolitan_area" title="London metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a> had a population of 12–14 million, depending on the definition used.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-metro_area_1_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-metro_area_1-250">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-metro2_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-metro2-251">[244]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>, London is the second <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe" title="List of metropolitan areas in Europe">most populous</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_commuter_belt" title="London commuter belt">metropolitan area</a> in Europe. A net 726,000 immigrants arrived there in the period 1991–2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immigration_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-Immigration-252">[245]</a></sup>
</p><p>The region covers 610 square miles (1,579 km<sup>2</sup>), giving a population density of 13,410 inhabitants per square mile (5,177/km<sup>2</sup>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[246]</a></sup> more than ten times that of any other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ITL_(UK)" title="ITL (UK)">British region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_087_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_087-254">[247]</a></sup> In population terms, London is the 19th <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_largest_cities" title="World's largest cities">largest city</a> and the 18th <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population" title="List of metropolitan areas by population">largest metropolitan</a> region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Billionaires_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-Billionaires-255">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_089_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_089-256">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Age_structure_and_median_age">Age structure and median age</span></h3>
<p>Children younger than 14 constituted 20.6% of the population in Outer London in 2018, and 18% in Inner London. The 15–24 age group was 11.1% in Outer and 10.2% in Inner London, those aged 25–44 years 30.6% in Outer London and 39.7% in Inner London, those aged 45–64 years 24% and 20.7% in Outer and Inner London respectively. Those aged 65 and over are 13.6% in Outer London, but only 9.3% in Inner London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-257">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Median_age" title="Median age">median age</a> of London in 2018 was 36.5, which was younger than the UK median of 40.3.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_257-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-257">[250]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_London" title="Ethnic groups in London">Ethnic groups in London</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:254px;max-width:254px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader" style="text-align:center">Maps of Greater London showing percentage distribution of selected ethnic groups according to the 2011 Census</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:White_Greater_London_2011_census.png"><img alt="White" data-file-height="16527" data-file-width="21396" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/White_Greater_London_2011_census.png/250px-White_Greater_London_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/White_Greater_London_2011_census.png/375px-White_Greater_London_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/White_Greater_London_2011_census.png/500px-White_Greater_London_2011_census.png 2x" width="250"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/White_people_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="White people in the United Kingdom">White</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asian_Greater_London_2011_census.png"><img alt="Asian" data-file-height="16527" data-file-width="21396" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Asian_Greater_London_2011_census.png/250px-Asian_Greater_London_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Asian_Greater_London_2011_census.png/375px-Asian_Greater_London_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Asian_Greater_London_2011_census.png/500px-Asian_Greater_London_2011_census.png 2x" width="250"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/British_Asian" title="British Asian">Asian</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Black_Greater_London_2011_census.png"><img alt="Black" data-file-height="16471" data-file-width="21322" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Black_Greater_London_2011_census.png/250px-Black_Greater_London_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Black_Greater_London_2011_census.png/375px-Black_Greater_London_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Black_Greater_London_2011_census.png/500px-Black_Greater_London_2011_census.png 2x" width="250"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Black_British_people" title="Black British people">Black</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a>, based on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011" title="United Kingdom Census 2011">2011 Census</a> estimates, 59.8 per cent of the 8,173,941 inhabitants of London were <a href="/wiki/White_people" title="White people">White</a>, with 44.9% <a href="/wiki/White_British" title="White British">White British</a>, 2.2% <a href="/wiki/Irish_migration_to_Great_Britain" title="Irish migration to Great Britain">White Irish</a>, 0.1% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gypsy_(term)" title="Gypsy (term)">gypsy</a>/<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irish_traveller" title="Irish traveller">Irish traveller</a> and 12.1% classified as <a href="/wiki/Other_White" title="Other White">Other White</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011censusdemo_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-2011censusdemo-258">[251]</a></sup> Meanwhile 20.9% of Londoners were of <a href="/wiki/British_Asian" title="British Asian">Asian</a> and mixed-Asian descent, 19.7% being of full Asian descents and those of mixed-Asian heritage 1.2% of the population. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Indian" title="British Indian">Indians</a> accounted for 6.6%, followed by <a href="/wiki/British_Pakistanis" title="British Pakistanis">Pakistanis</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Bangladeshi" title="British Bangladeshi">Bangladeshis</a> at 2.7% each. <a href="/wiki/British_Chinese" title="British Chinese">Chinese</a> peoples accounted for 1.5% and <a href="/wiki/British_Arabs" title="British Arabs">Arabs</a> for 1.3%. A further 4.9% were classified as "Other Asian".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011censusdemo_258-1"><a href="#cite_note-2011censusdemo-258">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>15.6% of London's population were of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_British" title="Black British">Black</a> and mixed-Black descent. 13.3% of full Black descent, with mixed-Black heritage comprising 2.3%. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_British" title="Black British">Black Africans</a> accounted for 7.0% of London's population, with 4.2% as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_African-Caribbean_community" title="British African-Caribbean community">Black Caribbean</a> and 2.1% as "Other Black". 5.0% were of <a href="/wiki/Mixed_(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category)" title="Mixed (United Kingdom ethnicity category)">mixed race</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011censusdemo_258-2"><a href="#cite_note-2011censusdemo-258">[251]</a></sup> The history of <a href="/wiki/History_of_African_presence_in_London" title="History of African presence in London">African presence in London</a> extends back to the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">Roman period</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2007, one fifth of primary school across London were from ethnic minorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_094_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_094-260">[253]</a></sup> Altogether at the 2011 census, of London's 1,624,768 population aged 0 to 15, 46.4% were White, 19.8% Asian, 19% Black, 10.8% Mixed and 4% another ethnic group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[254]</a></sup> In January 2005, a survey of London's ethnic and religious diversity claimed that more than 300 languages were spoken in London and more than 50 non-indigenous communities had populations of more than 10,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_090_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_090-262">[255]</a></sup> Figures from the <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> show that in 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=London&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, London's foreign-born population was 2,650,000 (33%), up from 1,630,000 in 1997.
</p><p>The 2011 census showed that 36.7% of <a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">Greater London</a>'s population were born outside the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_092_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_092-263">[256]</a></sup> Some of the German-born population were likely to be British nationals born to parents serving in the <a href="/wiki/British_Armed_Forces" title="British Armed Forces">British Armed Forces</a> in Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_095_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_095-264">[257]</a></sup> Estimates by the <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> indicate that the five largest foreign-born groups living in London in the period July 2009 to June 2010 were born in India, Poland, the Republic of Ireland, Bangladesh and Nigeria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Estimates_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-Estimates-265">[258]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_London" title="Religion in London">Religion in London</a></div>
<p>According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2011_UK_Census" title="2011 UK Census">2011 Census</a>, the largest religious groupings were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Christianity" title="British Christianity">Christians</a> (48.4%), followed by those of no religion (20.7%), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Muslims" title="British Muslims">Muslims</a> (12.4%), no response (8.5%), <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Hinduism in the United Kingdom">Hindus</a> (5.0%), Jews (1.8%), <a href="/wiki/Sikhism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Sikhism in the United Kingdom">Sikhs</a> (1.5%), <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Buddhism in the United Kingdom">Buddhists</a> (1.0%) and other (0.6%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[259]</a></sup>
</p><p>London has traditionally been Christian, and has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_churches_in_London" title="List of churches in London">large number of churches</a>, particularly in the City of London. The well-known <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul's Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a> in the City and <a href="/wiki/Southwark_Cathedral" title="Southwark Cathedral">Southwark Cathedral</a> south of the river are <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglican</a> administrative centres,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_096_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_096-267">[260]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury" title="Archbishop of Canterbury">Archbishop of Canterbury</a>, principal bishop of the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> and worldwide <a href="/wiki/Anglican_Communion" title="Anglican Communion">Anglican Communion</a>, has his main residence at <a href="/wiki/Lambeth_Palace" title="Lambeth Palace">Lambeth Palace</a> in the <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Lambeth" title="London Borough of Lambeth">London Borough of Lambeth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_097_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_097-268">[261]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_from_The_south_east.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1601" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_from_The_south_east.jpg/200px-St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_from_The_south_east.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_from_The_south_east.jpg/300px-St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_from_The_south_east.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_from_The_south_east.jpg/400px-St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_from_The_south_east.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul's Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a>, the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Bishop_of_London" title="Bishop of London">Bishop of London</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_Temple.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1489" data-file-width="2002" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/London_Temple.jpg/200px-London_Temple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/London_Temple.jpg/300px-London_Temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/London_Temple.jpg/400px-London_Temple.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/BAPS_Shri_Swaminarayan_Mandir_London" title="BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London">BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London</a> is the second-largest <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a> in England and Europe.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Important national and royal ceremonies are shared between <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul's Cathedral">St Paul's</a> and <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_098_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_098-269">[262]</a></sup> The Abbey is not to be confused with nearby <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Cathedral" title="Westminster Cathedral">Westminster Cathedral</a>, which is the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> cathedral in <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_099_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_099-270">[263]</a></sup> Despite the prevalence of Anglican churches, observance is low within the denomination. Church attendance continues a long, steady decline, according to Church of England statistics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_100_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_100-271">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>Notable mosques include the <a href="/wiki/East_London_Mosque" title="East London Mosque">East London Mosque</a> in Tower Hamlets, which is allowed to give the Islamic call to prayer through loudspeakers, the <a href="/wiki/London_Central_Mosque" title="London Central Mosque">London Central Mosque</a> on the edge of <a href="/wiki/Regent%27s_Park" title="Regent's Park">Regent's Park</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_101_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_101-272">[265]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baitul_Futuh" title="Baitul Futuh">Baitul Futuh</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya_Muslim_Community" title="Ahmadiyya Muslim Community">Ahmadiyya Muslim Community</a>. After the oil boom, increasing numbers of wealthy <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle-East" title="Middle-East">Middle-Eastern</a> Arab Muslims based themselves around <a href="/wiki/Mayfair" title="Mayfair">Mayfair</a>, Kensington and <a href="/wiki/Knightsbridge" title="Knightsbridge">Knightsbridge</a> in West London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_102_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_102-275">[268]</a></sup> There are large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslim" title="Bengali Muslim">Bengali Muslim</a> communities in the eastern boroughs of <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Tower_Hamlets" title="London Borough of Tower Hamlets">Tower Hamlets</a> and <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Newham" title="London Borough of Newham">Newham</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[269]</a></sup>
</p><p>Large Hindu communities are found in the north-western boroughs of <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Harrow" title="London Borough of Harrow">Harrow</a> and <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Brent" title="London Borough of Brent">Brent</a>, the latter hosting what was until 2006,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[270]</a></sup> Europe's largest <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neasden_Temple" title="Neasden Temple">Neasden Temple</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_103_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_103-278">[271]</a></sup> London is also home to 44 Hindu temples, including the <a href="/wiki/BAPS_Shri_Swaminarayan_Mandir_London" title="BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London">BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London</a>. There are Sikh communities in East and West London, particularly in Southall, home to one of the largest Sikh populations and the largest Sikh temple outside India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_104_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_104-279">[272]</a></sup>
</p><p>The majority of <a href="/wiki/British_Jews" title="British Jews">British Jews</a> live in London, with notable Jewish communities in <a href="/wiki/Stamford_Hill" title="Stamford Hill">Stamford Hill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanmore" title="Stanmore">Stanmore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golders_Green" title="Golders Green">Golders Green</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finchley" title="Finchley">Finchley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hampstead" title="Hampstead">Hampstead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hendon" title="Hendon">Hendon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edgware" title="Edgware">Edgware</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_London" title="North London">North London</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bevis_Marks_Synagogue" title="Bevis Marks Synagogue">Bevis Marks Synagogue</a> in the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a> is affiliated to London's historic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sephardic" title="Sephardic">Sephardic</a> Jewish community. It is the only synagogue in Europe to have held regular services continually for over 300 years. <a href="/wiki/Stanmore_and_Canons_Park_Synagogue" title="Stanmore and Canons Park Synagogue">Stanmore and Canons Park Synagogue</a> has the largest membership of any Orthodox synagogue in Europe, overtaking <a href="/wiki/Ilford" title="Ilford">Ilford</a> synagogue (also in London) in 1998.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_106_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_106-280">[273]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_Jewish_Forum" title="London Jewish Forum">London Jewish Forum</a> was set up in 2006 in response to the growing significance of devolved London Government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_107_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_107-281">[274]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Accents">Accents</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cockney" title="Cockney">Cockney</a> is an accent heard across London, mainly spoken by <a href="/wiki/Working_class" title="Working class">working-class</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lower_middle_class" title="Lower middle class">lower-middle class</a> Londoners. It is mainly attributed to the East End and wider East London, having originated there in the 18th century, although it has been suggested that the Cockney style of speech is much older.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[275]</a></sup> Some features of Cockney include, <a href="/wiki/Th-fronting" title="Th-fronting"><i>Th</i>-fronting</a> (pronouncing "th" as "f"), example, "some fings in life are bad" (heard in opening of "<a href="/wiki/Always_Look_on_the_Bright_Side_of_Life" title="Always Look on the Bright Side of Life">Always Look on the Bright Side of Life</a>" in <a href="/wiki/Monty_Python" title="Monty Python">Monty Python</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Monty_Python%27s_Life_of_Brian" title="Monty Python's Life of Brian">Life of Brian</a></i>), "th" inside a word is pronounced with a "v" (brother becomes brovva), <a href="/wiki/H-dropping" title="H-dropping"><i>H</i>-dropping</a>, example 'Ampshire for Hampshire (as <a href="/wiki/Eliza_Doolittle" title="Eliza Doolittle">Eliza Doolittle</a> said in <i>My Fair Lady</i>), and, like most English accents, a Cockney accent <a href="/wiki/Rhoticity_in_English" title="Rhoticity in English">drops the "r"</a> after a vowel, for example, "car" is pronounced "cah".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[276]</a></sup> John Camden Hotten, in his <i>Slang Dictionary</i> of 1859, makes reference to Cockney "use of a peculiar slang language" (<a href="/wiki/Rhyming_slang" title="Rhyming slang">Cockney rhyming slang</a>) when describing the <a href="/wiki/Costermonger" title="Costermonger">costermongers</a> of the East End. Examples include: using the word "treacle" to mean sweetheart (rhymes with <a href="/wiki/Treacle_tart" title="Treacle tart">Treacle tart</a>), and "porkies" to mean lies (rhymes with <a href="/wiki/Pork_pie" title="Pork pie">Pork pies</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[277]</a></sup> Since the start of the 21st century the Cockney dialect is less common in parts of the East End itself, with modern strongholds including other parts of London and suburbs in the <a href="/wiki/Home_counties" title="Home counties">home counties</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Estuary_English" title="Estuary English">Estuary English</a> is an intermediate accent between Cockney and <a href="/wiki/Received_Pronunciation" title="Received Pronunciation">Received Pronunciation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[280]</a></sup> It is widely spoken by people of all classes in London and south-eastern England, associated with the River Thames and its estuary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[281]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Multicultural_London_English" title="Multicultural London English">Multicultural London English</a> (MLE) is a <a href="/wiki/Multiethnolect" title="Multiethnolect">multiethnolect</a> becoming increasingly common in multicultural areas amongst young, working-class people from diverse backgrounds. It is a fusion of an array of ethnic accents, in particular Afro-Caribbean and South Asian, with a significant Cockney influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[282]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Received_Pronunciation" title="Received Pronunciation">Received Pronunciation</a> (RP) is the accent traditionally regarded as the standard for <a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">British English</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[283]</a></sup> It has no specific geographical correlate,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[284]</a></sup> although it is also traditionally defined as the standard speech used in London and south-eastern England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[285]</a></sup> It is mainly spoken by <a href="/wiki/Upper_class" title="Upper class">upper-class</a> and <a href="/wiki/Upper_middle_class" title="Upper middle class">upper-middle class</a> Londoners.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[287]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_London" title="Economy of London">Economy of London</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:City_of_London_skyline_from_London_City_Hall_-_Sept_2015_-_Crop_Aligned.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4668" data-file-width="8442" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/City_of_London_skyline_from_London_City_Hall_-_Sept_2015_-_Crop_Aligned.jpg/280px-City_of_London_skyline_from_London_City_Hall_-_Sept_2015_-_Crop_Aligned.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/City_of_London_skyline_from_London_City_Hall_-_Sept_2015_-_Crop_Aligned.jpg/420px-City_of_London_skyline_from_London_City_Hall_-_Sept_2015_-_Crop_Aligned.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/City_of_London_skyline_from_London_City_Hall_-_Sept_2015_-_Crop_Aligned.jpg/560px-City_of_London_skyline_from_London_City_Hall_-_Sept_2015_-_Crop_Aligned.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:City_of_London_skyline_from_London_City_Hall_-_Sept_2015_-_Crop_Aligned.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The City of London, one of the largest financial centres in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[288]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>London's <a href="/wiki/Gross_regional_product" title="Gross regional product">gross regional product</a> in 2019 was £503 billion, around a quarter of <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Economy of the United Kingdom">UK GDP</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[289]</a></sup> London has five major business districts: the city, Westminster, Canary Wharf, Camden &amp; Islington and Lambeth &amp; Southwark. One way to get an idea of their relative importance is to look at relative amounts of office space: Greater London had 27 million m<sup>2</sup> of office space in 2001, and the City contains the most space, with 8 million m<sup>2</sup> of office space. London has some of the highest real estate prices in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[291]</a></sup> London is the world's most expensive office market according to world property journal (2015) report.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[292]</a></sup> As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=London&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the residential property in London is worth $2.2 trillion – the same value as that of Brazil's annual GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[293]</a></sup> The city has the highest property prices of any European city according to the Office for National Statistics and the European Office of Statistics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[294]</a></sup> On average the price per square metre in central London is €24,252 (April 2014). This is higher than the property prices in other G8 European capital cities; Berlin €3,306, Rome €6,188 and Paris €11,229.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[295]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_City_of_London">The City of London</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paternoster_Square.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paternoster_Square.jpg/220px-Paternoster_Square.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paternoster_Square.jpg/330px-Paternoster_Square.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paternoster_Square.jpg/440px-Paternoster_Square.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paternoster_Square.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange" title="London Stock Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a> at <a href="/wiki/Paternoster_Square" title="Paternoster Square">Paternoster Square</a> and <a href="/wiki/Temple_Bar,_London" title="Temple Bar, London">Temple Bar</a></div></div></div>
<p>London's finance industry is based in the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a>, the two major <a href="/wiki/Central_business_district" title="Central business district">business districts</a> in London. London is one of the pre-eminent <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centres</a> of the world as the most important location for international finance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist1_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-economist1-303">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist2_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-economist2-304">[297]</a></sup> London took over as a major financial centre shortly after 1795 when the Dutch Republic collapsed before the Napoleonic armies. For many bankers established in Amsterdam (e.g. Hope, Baring), this was only time to move to London. Also, London's market-centred system (as opposed to the bank-centred one in Amsterdam) grew more dominant in the 18th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finance_Hub_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-Finance_Hub-88">[84]</a></sup> The London financial elite was strengthened by a strong Jewish community from all over Europe capable of mastering the most sophisticated financial tools of the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_94-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-94">[90]</a></sup> This unique concentration of talents accelerated the transition from the Commercial Revolution to the Industrial Revolution. Writing about capitalism and the utility of diversity in his book on English society, French philosopher Voltaire expounded upon why England at that time was more prosperous in comparison to the country's less religiously tolerant European neighbours:
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London,_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3418" data-file-width="4135" decoding="async" height="182" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif/lossy-page1-220px-Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif/lossy-page1-330px-Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif/lossy-page1-440px-Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London,_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London" title="Royal Exchange, London">Royal Exchange</a> in 1886</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Take a view of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London" title="Royal Exchange, London">Royal Exchange</a> in London, a place more venerable than many courts of justice, where the representatives of all nations meet for the benefit of mankind. There the Jew, the Mahometan [Muslim], and the Christian transact together, as though they all professed the same religion, and give the name of infidel to none but bankrupts. There the Presbyterian confides in the Anabaptist, and the Churchman depends on the Quaker's word. If one religion only were allowed in England, the Government would very possibly become arbitrary; if there were but two, the people would cut one another's throats; but as there are such a multitude, they all live happy and in peace.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/Voltaire" title="Voltaire">Voltaire</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Letters_on_the_English" title="Letters on the English">Letters on the English</a></i>, 1733.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[298]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London.bankofengland.arp.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1669" data-file-width="2047" decoding="async" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/London.bankofengland.arp.jpg/220px-London.bankofengland.arp.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/London.bankofengland.arp.jpg/330px-London.bankofengland.arp.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/London.bankofengland.arp.jpg/440px-London.bankofengland.arp.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:London.bankofengland.arp.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>, established in 1694, is the model on which most modern central banks are based.</div></div></div>
<p>By the mid-19th century, London was the leading financial centre, and at the end of the century over half the world's trade was financed in British currency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[299]</a></sup> Still, as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=London&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> London tops the world rankings on the <a href="/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index" title="Global Financial Centres Index">Global Financial Centres Index</a> (GFCI),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[300]</a></sup> and it ranked second in A.T. Kearney's 2018 Global Cities Index.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>London's largest industry is finance, and its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_export" title="Financial export">financial exports</a> make it a large contributor to the UK's <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_payments" title="Balance of payments">balance of payments</a>. Around 325,000 people were employed in financial services in London until mid-2007. London has over 480 overseas banks, more than any other city in the world. It is also the world's biggest currency trading centre, accounting for some 37 per cent of the $5.1 trillion average daily volume, according to the BIS.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[302]</a></sup> Over 85 per cent (3.2 million) of the employed population of greater London works in the services industries. Because of its prominent global role, London's economy had been affected by the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">financial crisis of 2007–2008</a>. However, by 2010 the city had recovered, put in place new regulatory powers, proceeded to regain lost ground and re-established London's economic dominance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[303]</a></sup> Along with <a href="/wiki/Professional_services" title="Professional services">professional services</a> headquarters, the City of London is home to the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange" title="London Stock Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lloyd%27s_of_London" title="Lloyd's of London">Lloyd's of London</a> insurance market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[304]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over half the UK's top 100 listed companies (the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FTSE_100" title="FTSE 100">FTSE 100</a>) and over 100 of Europe's 500 largest companies have their headquarters in central London.
