Over 70 per cent of the FTSE 100 are within London's metropolitan area, and 75 per cent of <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> companies have offices in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_113_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_113-312">[305]</a></sup> In a 1992 report commissioned by the London Stock Exchange, Sir <a href="/wiki/Adrian_Cadbury" title="Adrian Cadbury">Adrian Cadbury</a>, chairman of his family's confectionery company <a href="/wiki/Cadbury" title="Cadbury">Cadbury</a>, produced the <a href="/wiki/Cadbury_Report" title="Cadbury Report">Cadbury Report</a>, a code of best practice which served as a basis for reform of <a href="/wiki/Corporate_governance" title="Corporate governance">corporate governance</a> around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[306]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_technology">Media and technology</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:20191017_BBC_Studios_London,_BBC_Radio_Theatre,_New_Broadcasting_House_photo_by_Amy_Karle.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/20191017_BBC_Studios_London%2C_BBC_Radio_Theatre%2C_New_Broadcasting_House_photo_by_Amy_Karle.jpg/220px-20191017_BBC_Studios_London%2C_BBC_Radio_Theatre%2C_New_Broadcasting_House_photo_by_Amy_Karle.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/20191017_BBC_Studios_London%2C_BBC_Radio_Theatre%2C_New_Broadcasting_House_photo_by_Amy_Karle.jpg/330px-20191017_BBC_Studios_London%2C_BBC_Radio_Theatre%2C_New_Broadcasting_House_photo_by_Amy_Karle.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/20191017_BBC_Studios_London%2C_BBC_Radio_Theatre%2C_New_Broadcasting_House_photo_by_Amy_Karle.jpg/440px-20191017_BBC_Studios_London%2C_BBC_Radio_Theatre%2C_New_Broadcasting_House_photo_by_Amy_Karle.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:20191017_BBC_Studios_London,_BBC_Radio_Theatre,_New_Broadcasting_House_photo_by_Amy_Karle.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Broadcasting_House" title="Broadcasting House">Broadcasting House</a> in central London, headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a></div></div></div>
<p>Media companies are <a href="/wiki/Media_in_London" title="Media in London">concentrated in London</a>, and the media distribution industry is London's second most competitive sector.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_114_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_114-314">[307]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> is a significant employer, while other broadcasters also have headquarters around the city. Many <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of newspapers in the United Kingdom">national newspapers</a> are edited in London; the term <a href="/wiki/Fleet_Street" title="Fleet Street">Fleet Street</a> (where most national newspapers operated) remains a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metonym" title="Metonym">metonym</a> for the British national press. London is a major retail centre and in 2010 had the highest non-food retail sales of any city in the world, with a total spend of around £64.2 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[308]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London" title="Port of London">Port of London</a> is the second largest in the UK, handling 45 million <a href="/wiki/Tonne" title="Tonne">tonnes</a> of cargo each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-handling_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-handling-316">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p>A growing number of technology companies are based in London, notably in <a href="/wiki/East_London_Tech_City" title="East London Tech City">East London Tech City</a>, also known as Silicon Roundabout. In 2014 the city was among the first to receive a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GeoTLD" title="GeoTLD">geoTLD</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[312]</a></sup> In February 2014 London was ranked as the European City of the Future<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[313]</a></sup> in the 2014/15 list by <i><a href="/wiki/FDi_Intelligence" title="FDi Intelligence">fDi Intelligence</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[314]</a></sup> Computer science pioneer <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">Alan Turing</a> hails from <a href="/wiki/Maida_Vale" title="Maida Vale">Maida Vale</a>, west London. A museum in <a href="/wiki/Bletchley_Park" title="Bletchley Park">Bletchley Park</a>, where Turing was based during World War II, is located in <a href="/wiki/Bletchley" title="Bletchley">Bletchley</a>, 40 miles (64 km) north of central London, as is <a href="/wiki/The_National_Museum_of_Computing" title="The National Museum of Computing">The National Museum of Computing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[315]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[316]</a></sup>
</p><p>The gas and electricity distribution networks that manage and operate the towers, cables and pressure systems that deliver energy to consumers across the city are managed by <a href="/wiki/National_Grid_plc" title="National Grid plc">National Grid plc</a>, <a href="/wiki/SGN_(company)" title="SGN (company)">SGN</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[317]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/UK_Power_Networks" title="UK Power Networks">UK Power Networks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[318]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_London" title="Tourism in London">Tourism in London</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:British_Museum_from_NE_2_(cropped).JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1593" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG/200px-British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG/300px-British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG/400px-British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-07,_DD_036.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2662" data-file-width="5023" decoding="async" height="106" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG/200px-Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG/300px-Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG/400px-Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>London is one of the leading tourist destinations in the world and in 2015 was ranked as the most visited city in the world with over 65 million visits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[320]</a></sup> It is also the top city in the world by visitor cross-border spending, estimated at US$20.23 billion in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[321]</a></sup> Tourism is one of London's prime industries, employing 700,000 full-time workers in 2016, and contributes £36 billion a year to the economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[322]</a></sup> The city accounts for 54% of all inbound visitor spending in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[323]</a></sup> As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=London&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> London was the world top city destination as ranked by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TripAdvisor" title="TripAdvisor">TripAdvisor</a> users.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2015 the top most-visited attractions in the UK were all in London. The top 10 most visited attractions were: (with visits per venue)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[325]</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li><a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a>: 6,820,686</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a>: 5,908,254</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London" title="Natural History Museum, London">Natural History Museum</a> (South Kensington): 5,284,023</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Southbank_Centre" title="Southbank Centre">Southbank Centre</a>: 5,102,883</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a>: 4,712,581</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum" title="Victoria and Albert Museum">Victoria and Albert Museum</a> (South Kensington): 3,432,325</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Science_Museum,_London" title="Science Museum, London">Science Museum</a>: 3,356,212</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Somerset_House" title="Somerset House">Somerset House</a>: 3,235,104</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a>: 2,785,249</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery,_London" title="National Portrait Gallery, London">National Portrait Gallery</a>: 2,145,486</li></ol>
<p>The number of hotel rooms in London in 2015 stood at 138,769, and is expected to grow over the years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[326]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_London" title="Transport in London">Transport in London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Infrastructure_in_London" title="Infrastructure in London">Infrastructure in London</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Transport_in_London.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="673" data-file-width="1441" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Transport_in_London.png/260px-Transport_in_London.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Transport_in_London.png/390px-Transport_in_London.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Transport_in_London.png/520px-Transport_in_London.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Transport_in_London.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Journeys in Greater London by mode from 1997 to 2018<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[327]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Transport is one of the four main areas of policy administered by the Mayor of London,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_121_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_121-335">[328]</a></sup> but the mayor's financial control does not extend to the longer-distance rail network that enters London. In 2007 the Mayor of London assumed responsibility for some local lines, which now form the <a href="/wiki/London_Overground" title="London Overground">London Overground</a> network, adding to the existing responsibility for the London Underground, trams and buses. The public transport network is administered by <a href="/wiki/Transport_for_London" title="Transport for London">Transport for London</a> (TfL).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[329]</a></sup>
</p><p>The lines that formed the London Underground, as well as trams and buses, became part of an integrated transport system in 1933 when the <a href="/wiki/London_Passenger_Transport_Board" title="London Passenger Transport Board">London Passenger Transport Board</a> or <i><a href="/wiki/London_Transport_(brand)" title="London Transport (brand)">London Transport</a></i> was created. Transport for London is now the statutory corporation responsible for most aspects of the transport system in Greater London, and is run by a board and a commissioner appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_London" title="Mayor of London">Mayor of London</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat_tfl_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-stat_tfl-337">[330]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Aviation">Aviation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Airports_of_London" title="Airports of London">Airports of London</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="797" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg/220px-Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg/330px-Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg/440px-Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Airport" title="Heathrow Airport">Heathrow Airport</a> is the busiest airport in Europe as well as the second busiest in the world for international passenger traffic. (<a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Terminal_5" title="Heathrow Terminal 5">Terminal 5</a>C is pictured.)</div></div></div>
<p>London is a major international air transport hub with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_city_airport_systems_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest city airport systems by passenger traffic">busiest city airspace in the world</a>. Eight airports use the word <i>London</i> in their name, but most traffic passes through six of these. Additionally, <a href="/wiki/Airports_of_London" title="Airports of London">various other airports</a> also serve London, catering primarily to <a href="/wiki/General_aviation" title="General aviation">general aviation</a> flights.
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Airport" title="Heathrow Airport">Heathrow Airport</a>, in <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Hillingdon" title="London Borough of Hillingdon">Hillingdon</a>, West London, was for many years the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airport" title="World's busiest airport">busiest airport in the world</a> for international traffic, and is the major hub of the nation's flag carrier, <a href="/wiki/British_Airways" title="British Airways">British Airways</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_135_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_135-338">[331]</a></sup> In March 2008 its fifth terminal was opened.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_137_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_137-339">[332]</a></sup> In 2014, <a href="/wiki/Dubai_International_Airport" title="Dubai International Airport">Dubai</a> gained from Heathrow the leading position in terms of international passenger traffic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[333]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gatwick_Airport" title="Gatwick Airport">Gatwick Airport</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_139_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_139-341">[334]</a></sup> south of London in <a href="/wiki/West_Sussex" title="West Sussex">West Sussex</a>, handles flights to more destinations than any other UK airport<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[335]</a></sup> and is the main base of <a href="/wiki/EasyJet" title="EasyJet">easyJet</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[336]</a></sup> the UK's largest airline by number of passengers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[337]</a></sup></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stansted_Airport" title="Stansted Airport">Stansted Airport</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_140_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_140-345">[338]</a></sup> north-east of London in <a href="/wiki/Essex" title="Essex">Essex</a>, has flights that serve the greatest number of European destinations of any UK airport<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[339]</a></sup> and is the main base of <a href="/wiki/Ryanair" title="Ryanair">Ryanair</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[340]</a></sup> the world's largest international airline by number of international passengers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[341]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Luton_Airport" title="Luton Airport">Luton Airport</a>, to the north of London in <a href="/wiki/Bedfordshire" title="Bedfordshire">Bedfordshire</a>, is used by several budget airlines (especially easyJet and <a href="/wiki/Wizz_Air" title="Wizz Air">Wizz Air</a>) for short-haul flights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_141_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_141-349">[342]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/London_City_Airport" title="London City Airport">London City Airport</a>, the most central airport and the one with the shortest runway, in <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Newham" title="London Borough of Newham">Newham</a>, East London, is focused on business travellers, with a mixture of full-service short-haul scheduled flights and considerable <a href="/wiki/Business_jet" title="Business jet">business jet</a> traffic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_142_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_142-350">[343]</a></sup></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southend_Airport" title="Southend Airport">Southend Airport</a>, east of London in <a href="/wiki/Essex" title="Essex">Essex</a>, is a smaller, regional airport that caters for short-haul flights on a limited, though growing, number of airlines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[344]</a></sup> In 2017, international passengers made up over 95% of the total at Southend, the highest proportion of any London airport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[345]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rail">Rail</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Underground_and_DLR">Underground and DLR</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3102" data-file-width="4452" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg/220px-Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg/330px-Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg/440px-Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a> is the world's oldest and third-longest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> system.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a>, commonly referred to as the Tube or just the Underground, is the oldest<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Metro_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-Metro-353">[346]</a></sup> and third longest<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-citymetric.com_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-citymetric.com-354">[347]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">metro</a> system in the world. The system serves <a href="/wiki/List_of_London_Underground_stations" title="List of London Underground stations">272 stations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-facts_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-facts-355">[348]</a></sup> and was formed from several private companies, including the world's first underground electric line, the <a href="/wiki/City_and_South_London_Railway" title="City and South London Railway">City and South London Railway</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UrbanRail_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-UrbanRail-356">[349]</a></sup> It dates from 1863.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Metro150_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-Metro150-357">[350]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over four million journeys are made every day on the Underground network, over 1 billion each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_124_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_124-358">[351]</a></sup> An investment programme is attempting to reduce congestion and improve reliability, including £6.5 billion (€7.7 billion) spent before the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[352]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Docklands_Light_Railway" title="Docklands Light Railway">Docklands Light Railway (DLR)</a>, which opened in 1987, is a second, more <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medium-capacity_rail_transport_system" title="Medium-capacity rail transport system">local metro system</a> using smaller and lighter tram-type vehicles that serve the <a href="/wiki/London_Docklands" title="London Docklands">Docklands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greenwich" title="Greenwich">Greenwich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lewisham" title="Lewisham">Lewisham</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Suburban">Suburban</span></h4>
<p>There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_London_railway_stations" title="List of London railway stations">368 railway stations</a> in the <a href="/wiki/London_fare_zones" title="London fare zones">London Travelcard Zones</a> on an extensive above-ground suburban railway network. South London, particularly, has a high concentration of railways as it has fewer Underground lines. Most rail lines terminate around the centre of London, running into <a href="/wiki/London_station_group" title="London station group">eighteen terminal stations</a>, with the exception of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thameslink_(route)" title="Thameslink (route)">Thameslink</a> trains connecting <a href="/wiki/Bedford" title="Bedford">Bedford</a> in the north and <a href="/wiki/Brighton" title="Brighton">Brighton</a> in the south via <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Luton_Airport" title="London Luton Airport">Luton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gatwick_Airport" title="Gatwick Airport">Gatwick</a> airports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_127_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_127-360">[353]</a></sup> London has Britain's busiest station by number of passengers—<a href="/wiki/London_Waterloo_station" title="London Waterloo station">Waterloo</a>, with over 184 million people using the interchange station complex (which includes <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Waterloo_East_railway_station" title="London Waterloo East railway station">Waterloo East</a> station) each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-National_Rail_Station_Usage_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-National_Rail_Station_Usage-361">[354]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tube_exits_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tube_exits-362">[355]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Clapham_Junction_railway_station" title="Clapham Junction railway station">Clapham Junction</a> is the busiest station in Europe by the number of trains passing.
</p><p>With the need for more rail capacity in London, the <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_line" title="Elizabeth line">Elizabeth Line</a> (also known as Crossrail) opened in May 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[356]</a></sup> It is a new railway line running east to west through London and into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Home_Counties" title="Home Counties">Home Counties</a> with a branch to <a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Airport" title="Heathrow Airport">Heathrow Airport</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[357]</a></sup> It was Europe's biggest construction project, with a £15 billion projected cost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[358]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[359]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Inter-city_and_international">Inter-city and international</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7140" data-file-width="8466" decoding="async" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/220px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/330px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/440px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station" title="St Pancras railway station">St Pancras International</a> is the main terminal for high-speed <a href="/wiki/Eurostar" title="Eurostar">Eurostar</a> and <a href="/wiki/High_Speed_1" title="High Speed 1">High Speed 1</a> services, as well as commuter suburban Thameslink and inter-city <a href="/wiki/East_Midlands_Railway" title="East Midlands Railway">East Midlands Railway</a> services.</div></div></div>
<p>London is the centre of the <a href="/wiki/National_Rail" title="National Rail">National Rail</a> network, with 70 per cent of rail journeys starting or ending in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[360]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/London_King%27s_Cross_railway_station" title="London King's Cross railway station">King's Cross station</a> and <a href="/wiki/Euston_railway_station" title="Euston railway station">Euston station</a>, which are both in London, are the starting points of the <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_Main_Line" title="East Coast Main Line">East Coast Main Line</a> and the <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_Main_Line" title="West Coast Main Line">West Coast Main Line</a> – the two main railway lines in Britain. Like suburban rail services, regional and inter-city trains depart from several termini around the city centre, directly linking London with most of Great Britain's major cities and towns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[361]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some international railway services to <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">Continental Europe</a> were operated during the 20th century as <a href="/wiki/Boat_train" title="Boat train">boat trains</a>, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Admiraal_de_Ruijter_(train)" title="Admiraal de Ruijter (train)">Admiraal de Ruijter</a></i> to <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Night_Ferry" title="Night Ferry">Night Ferry</a></i> to Paris and Brussels. The opening of the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a> in 1994 connected London directly to the continental rail network, allowing <a href="/wiki/Eurostar" title="Eurostar">Eurostar</a> services to begin. Since 2007, high-speed trains link <a href="/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station" title="St Pancras railway station">St. Pancras International</a> with <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">Lille</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calais" title="Calais">Calais</a>, Paris, <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Paris" title="Disneyland Paris">Disneyland Paris</a>, Brussels, <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a> and other European tourist destinations via the <a href="/wiki/High_Speed_1" title="High Speed 1">High Speed 1</a> rail link and the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[362]</a></sup> The first <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_(train_operating_company)" title="Southeastern (train operating company)">high-speed domestic</a> trains started in June 2009 linking <a href="/wiki/Kent" title="Kent">Kent</a> to London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Southeastern_Highspeed_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-Southeastern_Highspeed-370">[363]</a></sup> There are plans for a <a href="/wiki/High_Speed_2" title="High Speed 2">second high speed line</a> linking London to the Midlands, North West England, and Yorkshire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[364]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Freight">Freight</span></h4>
<p>Although <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rail_freight" title="Rail freight">rail freight</a> levels are far down compared to their height, significant quantities of cargo are also carried into and out of London by rail; chiefly building materials and <a href="/wiki/Landfill" title="Landfill">landfill</a> waste. As a major hub of the British railway network, London's tracks also carry large amounts of freight for the other regions, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Containerisation" title="Containerisation">container freight</a> from the Channel Tunnel and <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> ports, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_waste" title="Nuclear waste">nuclear waste</a> for <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reprocessing" title="Nuclear reprocessing">reprocessing</a> at <a href="/wiki/Sellafield" title="Sellafield">Sellafield</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Freight_Plan_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-Freight_Plan-372">[365]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Buses.2C_coaches_and_trams"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Buses,_coaches_and_trams">Buses, coaches and trams</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GOOD_MORNING_BORIS_-_Flickr_-_secret_coach_park.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1596" data-file-width="2391" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/GOOD_MORNING_BORIS_-_Flickr_-_secret_coach_park.jpg/220px-GOOD_MORNING_BORIS_-_Flickr_-_secret_coach_park.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/GOOD_MORNING_BORIS_-_Flickr_-_secret_coach_park.jpg/330px-GOOD_MORNING_BORIS_-_Flickr_-_secret_coach_park.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/GOOD_MORNING_BORIS_-_Flickr_-_secret_coach_park.jpg/440px-GOOD_MORNING_BORIS_-_Flickr_-_secret_coach_park.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GOOD_MORNING_BORIS_-_Flickr_-_secret_coach_park.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/New_Routemaster" title="New Routemaster">New Routemaster</a> (which replaced the <a href="/wiki/AEC_Routemaster" title="AEC Routemaster">AEC Routemaster</a>) entered service in 2012. The red double-decker bus is an emblematic symbol of London.</div></div></div>
<p>London's <a href="/wiki/London_Buses" title="London Buses">bus network</a> runs 24 hours a day with about 9,300 vehicles, over 675 bus routes and about 19,000 bus stops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buses_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-Buses-373">[366]</a></sup> In 2019/1920 the network had over 2 billion commuter trips per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[367]</a></sup> Since 2010 and average of £1.2 billion is taken in revenue each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[368]</a></sup> London has one of the largest wheelchair-accessible networks in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_131_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_131-376">[369]</a></sup> and from the third quarter of 2007, became more accessible to hearing and visually impaired passengers as audio-visual announcements were introduced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>London's coach hub is <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Coach_Station" title="Victoria Coach Station">Victoria Coach Station</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> building opened in 1932. The coach station was initially run by a group of coach companies under the name of London Coastal Coaches; however, in 1970 the service and station were included in the nationalisation of the country's coach services, becoming part of the National Bus Company. In 1988, the coach station was purchased by London Transport which then became <a href="/wiki/Transport_for_London" title="Transport for London">Transport for London</a>. Victoria Coach Station has over 14 million passengers a year and provides services across the UK and continental Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[371]</a></sup>
</p><p>London has a modern tram network, known as <a href="/wiki/Tramlink" title="Tramlink">Tramlink</a>, centred on <a href="/wiki/Croydon" title="Croydon">Croydon</a> in <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South London</a>. The network has 39 stops and four routes, and carried 28 million people in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[372]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[373]</a></sup> Since June 2008, <a href="/wiki/Transport_for_London" title="Transport for London">Transport for London</a> has completely owned and operated Tramlink.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[374]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cable_car">Cable car</span></h3>
<p>London's first and to date only cable car is the <a href="/wiki/London_Cable_Car" title="London Cable Car">London Cable Car</a>, which opened in June 2012. The cable car crosses the Thames and links <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Peninsula" title="Greenwich Peninsula">Greenwich Peninsula</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Docks" title="Royal Docks">Royal Docks</a> in the east of the city. It is integrated with London's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oyster_Card" title="Oyster Card">Oyster Card</a> ticketing system, although the Emirates Air Line fares are not included in the Oyster daily capping.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[375]</a></sup> It cost £60 million to build and can carry up to 2,500 passengers per hour in each direction at peak times. Similar to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Cycle_Hire_Scheme" title="London Cycle Hire Scheme">London Cycle Hire Scheme</a> bike hire scheme, the cable car was sponsored in a 10-year deal by the airline <a href="/wiki/Emirates_(airline)" title="Emirates (airline)">Emirates</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[376]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cycling">Cycling</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cycling_in_London" title="Cycling in London">Cycling in London</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Belgrave_Road,_Victoria,_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3216" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg/220px-Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg/330px-Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg/440px-Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Belgrave_Road,_Victoria,_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Santander Cycle Hire near <a href="/wiki/Victoria,_London" title="Victoria, London">Victoria</a> in Central London</div></div></div>
<p>In the Greater London Area, around 670,000 people use a bike every day,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[377]</a></sup> meaning around 7% of the total population of around 8.8 million use a bike on an average day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[378]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[379]</a></sup> This relatively low percentage of bicycle users may be due to the poor investments for cycling in London of about £110 million per year,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[380]</a></sup> equating to around £12 per person, which can be compared to £22 in the Netherlands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[381]</a></sup>
</p><p>Cycling has become an increasingly popular way to get around London. The launch of a <a href="/wiki/Bicycle-sharing_system" title="Bicycle-sharing system">bicycle hire scheme</a> in July 2010 was successful and generally well received.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[382]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Port_and_river_boats">Port and river boats</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London" title="Port of London">Port of London</a>, once the largest in the world, is now only the second-largest in the United Kingdom, handling 45 million tonnes of cargo each year as of 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-handling_316-1"><a href="#cite_note-handling-316">[309]</a></sup> Most of this cargo passes through the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Tilbury" title="Port of Tilbury">Port of Tilbury</a>, outside the boundary of Greater London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-handling_316-2"><a href="#cite_note-handling-316">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p>London has river boat services on the Thames known as <a href="/wiki/Thames_Clippers" title="Thames Clippers">Thames Clippers</a>, which offer both commuter and tourist boat services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[383]</a></sup> At major piers including <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf_Pier" title="Canary Wharf Pier">Canary Wharf</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Bridge_City_Pier" title="London Bridge City Pier">London Bridge City</a>, Battersea Power Station and <a href="/wiki/London_Eye_Pier" title="London Eye Pier">London Eye</a> (Waterloo), services depart at least every 20 minutes during commuter times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[384]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Woolwich_Ferry" title="Woolwich Ferry">Woolwich Ferry</a>, with 2.5 million passengers every year, is a frequent service linking the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Circular_Road,_London" title="North Circular Road, London">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Circular_Road,_London" title="South Circular Road, London">South Circular</a> Roads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[385]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Roads">Roads</span></h3>
<p>Although the majority of journeys in central London are made by public transport, car travel is common in the suburbs. The <a href="/wiki/London_Inner_Ring_Road" title="London Inner Ring Road">inner ring road</a> (around the city centre), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A406_road" title="A406 road">North</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A205_road" title="A205 road">South Circular</a> roads (just within the suburbs), and the outer orbital motorway (the <a href="/wiki/M25_motorway" title="M25 motorway">M25</a>, just outside the built-up area in most places) encircle the city and are intersected by a number of busy radial routes—but very few motorways penetrate into <a href="/wiki/Inner_London" title="Inner London">inner London</a>. A plan for a comprehensive network of motorways throughout the city (the <a href="/wiki/London_Ringways" title="London Ringways">Ringways Plan</a>) was prepared in the 1960s but was mostly cancelled in the early 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[386]</a></sup> The M25 is the second-longest ring-road motorway in Europe at 117 miles (188 km) long.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[387]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/A1_road_(Great_Britain)" title="A1 road (Great Britain)">A1</a> and <a href="/wiki/M1_motorway" title="M1 motorway">M1</a> connect London to <a href="/wiki/Leeds" title="Leeds">Leeds</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne" title="Newcastle upon Tyne">Newcastle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Black_London_Cab.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="605" data-file-width="809" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Black_London_Cab.jpg/220px-Black_London_Cab.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Black_London_Cab.jpg/330px-Black_London_Cab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Black_London_Cab.jpg/440px-Black_London_Cab.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Black_London_Cab.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Hackney_carriage" title="Hackney carriage">hackney carriage</a> (black cab) is a common sight on London streets. Although traditionally black, this is not a requirement with some painted in other colours or bearing advertising.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Austin_Motor_Company" title="Austin Motor Company">Austin Motor Company</a> began making <a href="/wiki/Hackney_carriage" title="Hackney carriage">hackney carriages</a> (London taxis) in 1929, and models include <a href="/wiki/Austin_FX3" title="Austin FX3">Austin FX3</a> from 1948, <a href="/wiki/Austin_FX4" title="Austin FX4">Austin FX4</a> from 1958, with more recent models <a href="/wiki/TXII" title="TXII">TXII</a> and <a href="/wiki/TX4" title="TX4">TX4</a> manufactured by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Taxis_International" title="London Taxis International">London Taxis International</a>. The BBC states, "ubiquitous black cabs and red double-decker buses all have long and tangled stories that are deeply embedded in London’s traditions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London_traditions_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-London_traditions-395">[388]</a></sup>
</p><p>London is notorious for its traffic congestion; in 2009, the average speed of a car in the rush hour was recorded at 10.6 mph (17.1 km/h).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_147_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_147-396">[389]</a></sup> In 2003, a <a href="/wiki/London_congestion_charge" title="London congestion charge">congestion charge</a> was introduced to reduce traffic volumes in the city centre. With a few exceptions, motorists are required to pay to drive within a defined zone encompassing much of central London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[390]</a></sup> Motorists who are residents of the defined zone can buy a greatly reduced season pass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_146_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_146-398">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[392]</a></sup> The London government initially expected the Congestion Charge Zone to increase daily peak period Underground and bus users, reduce road traffic, increase traffic speeds, and reduce queues;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[393]</a></sup> however, the increase in private for hire vehicles has affected these expectations. Over the course of several years, the average number of cars entering the centre of London on a weekday was reduced from 195,000 to 125,000 cars – a 35-per-cent reduction of vehicles driven per day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[395]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_London" title="Education in London">Education in London</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tertiary_education">Tertiary education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_higher_education_colleges_in_London" title="List of universities and higher education colleges in London">List of universities and higher education colleges in London</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Main_entrance,_Imperial_College,_London_(geograph_5751173).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="428" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Main_entrance%2C_Imperial_College%2C_London_%28geograph_5751173%29.jpg/220px-Main_entrance%2C_Imperial_College%2C_London_%28geograph_5751173%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Main_entrance%2C_Imperial_College%2C_London_%28geograph_5751173%29.jpg/330px-Main_entrance%2C_Imperial_College%2C_London_%28geograph_5751173%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Main_entrance%2C_Imperial_College%2C_London_%28geograph_5751173%29.jpg/440px-Main_entrance%2C_Imperial_College%2C_London_%28geograph_5751173%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Main_entrance,_Imperial_College,_London_(geograph_5751173).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College London</a>, a technical research university in <a href="/wiki/South_Kensington" title="South Kensington">South Kensington</a></div></div></div>
<p>London is a major global centre of higher education teaching and research and has the largest concentration of higher education institutes in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london2_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-london2-24">[21]</a></sup> According to the QS World University Rankings 2015/16, London has the greatest concentration of top class universities in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[397]</a></sup> and its international student population of around 110,000 is larger than any other city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[398]</a></sup> A 2014 <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">PricewaterhouseCoopers</a> report termed London the global capital of higher education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[399]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KCL_embankment_facade.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/KCL_embankment_facade.jpg/220px-KCL_embankment_facade.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/KCL_embankment_facade.jpg/330px-KCL_embankment_facade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/KCL_embankment_facade.jpg/440px-KCL_embankment_facade.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KCL_embankment_facade.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London" title="King's College London">King's College London</a>, established by Royal Charter in 1829, is one of the founding colleges of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_London" title="University of London">University of London</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>A number of world-leading education institutions are based in London. In the 2022 <i><a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College London</a> is ranked No. 6 in the world, <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a> (UCL) is ranked 8th, and <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London" title="King's College London">King's College London</a> (KCL) is ranked 37th.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[400]</a></sup> All are regularly ranked highly, with Imperial College being the UK's leading university in the <a href="/wiki/Research_Excellence_Framework" title="Research Excellence Framework">Research Excellence Framework</a> ranking 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[401]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Economics" title="London School of Economics">London School of Economics</a> has been described as the world's leading social science institution for both teaching and research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_156_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_156-409">[402]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_Business_School" title="London Business School">London Business School</a> is considered one of the world's leading business schools and in 2015 its MBA programme was ranked second-best in the world by the <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ft_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-ft-410">[403]</a></sup> The city is also home to three of the world's top ten performing arts schools (as ranked by the 2020 QS World University Rankings<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[404]</a></sup>): the <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music" title="Royal College of Music">Royal College of Music</a> (ranking 2nd in the world), the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music" title="Royal Academy of Music">Royal Academy of Music</a> (ranking 4th) and the <a href="/wiki/Guildhall_School_of_Music_and_Drama" title="Guildhall School of Music and Drama">Guildhall School of Music and Drama</a> (ranking 6th).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[405]</a></sup>
</p><p>With  students in London<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HESA_citation_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-HESA_citation-413">[406]</a></sup> and around 48,000 in <a href="/wiki/University_of_London_Worldwide" title="University of London Worldwide">University of London Worldwide</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-External_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-External-414">[407]</a></sup> the federal <a href="/wiki/University_of_London" title="University of London">University of London</a> is the largest contact teaching university in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[408]</a></sup> It includes five multi-faculty universities – <a href="/wiki/City,_University_of_London" title="City, University of London">City</a>, King's College London, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_Mary,_University_of_London" title="Queen Mary, University of London">Queen Mary</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Holloway" title="Royal Holloway">Royal Holloway</a> and UCL – and a number of smaller and more specialised institutions including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Birkbeck_College" title="Birkbeck College">Birkbeck</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Courtauld_Institute_of_Art" title="Courtauld Institute of Art">Courtauld Institute of Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goldsmiths,_University_of_London" title="Goldsmiths, University of London">Goldsmiths</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_Business_School" title="London Business School">London Business School</a>, the London School of Economics, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_School_of_Hygiene_%26_Tropical_Medicine" title="London School of Hygiene &amp; Tropical Medicine">London School of Hygiene &amp; Tropical Medicine</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music" title="Royal Academy of Music">Royal Academy of Music</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_School_of_Speech_and_Drama" title="Central School of Speech and Drama">Central School of Speech and Drama</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Veterinary_College" title="Royal Veterinary College">Royal Veterinary College</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/School_of_Oriental_and_African_Studies" title="School of Oriental and African Studies">School of Oriental and African Studies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[409]</a></sup> Members of the University of London have their own <a href="/wiki/University_and_college_admission" title="University and college admission">admissions</a> procedures, and most award their own degrees.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alexander_Fleming_site.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Alexander_Fleming_site.jpg/170px-Alexander_Fleming_site.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Alexander_Fleming_site.jpg/255px-Alexander_Fleming_site.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Alexander_Fleming_site.jpg/340px-Alexander_Fleming_site.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alexander_Fleming_site.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St_Mary%27s_Hospital,_London" title="St Mary's Hospital, London">St Mary's Hospital</a>, a constituent of <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_School_of_Medicine" title="Imperial College School of Medicine">Imperial College School of Medicine</a>, where in 1928 <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Fleming" title="Alexander Fleming">Alexander Fleming</a> discovered penicillin in the second floor laboratory.</div></div></div>
<p>A number of universities in London are outside the University of London system, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brunel_University" title="Brunel University">Brunel University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College London</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[note 6]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kingston_University" title="Kingston University">Kingston University</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Metropolitan_University" title="London Metropolitan University">London Metropolitan University</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_157_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_157-418">[410]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/University_of_East_London" title="University of East London">University of East London</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_West_London" title="University of West London">University of West London</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Westminster" title="University of Westminster">University of Westminster</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_South_Bank_University" title="London South Bank University">London South Bank University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middlesex_University" title="Middlesex University">Middlesex University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Arts_London" title="University of the Arts London">University of the Arts London</a> (the largest university of art, design, fashion, communication and the performing arts in Europe).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[411]</a></sup> In addition, there are three international universities in London – <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regent%27s_College" title="Regent's College">Regent's University London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richmond,_The_American_International_University_in_London" title="Richmond, The American International University in London">Richmond, The American International University in London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Schiller_International_University" title="Schiller International University">Schiller International University</a>.
</p><p>London is home to <a href="/wiki/United_Hospitals" title="United Hospitals">five major medical schools</a> – <a href="/wiki/Barts_and_The_London_School_of_Medicine_and_Dentistry" title="Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry">Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry</a> (part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_Mary,_University_of_London" title="Queen Mary, University of London">Queen Mary</a>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London_School_of_Medicine" title="King's College London School of Medicine">King's College London School of Medicine</a> (the largest medical school in Europe), <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_School_of_Medicine" title="Imperial College School of Medicine">Imperial College School of Medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/UCL_Medical_School" title="UCL Medical School">UCL Medical School</a> and <a href="/wiki/St_George%27s,_University_of_London" title="St George's, University of London">St George's, University of London</a> – and has many affiliated teaching hospitals. It is also a major centre for biomedical research, and three of the UK's eight <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academic_health_science_centre" title="Academic health science centre">academic health science centres</a> are based in the city – <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_Healthcare_NHS_Trust" title="Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust">Imperial College Healthcare</a>, <a href="/wiki/King%27s_Health_Partners" title="King's Health Partners">King's Health Partners</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UCL_Partners" title="UCL Partners">UCL Partners</a> (the largest such centre in Europe).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[412]</a></sup> Additionally, many biomedical and biotechnology spin out companies from these research institutions are based around the city, most prominently in <a href="/wiki/White_City,_London" title="White City, London">White City</a>. Founded by pioneering nurse <a href="/wiki/Florence_Nightingale" title="Florence Nightingale">Florence Nightingale</a> at <a href="/wiki/St_Thomas%27_Hospital" title="St Thomas' Hospital">St Thomas' Hospital</a> in 1860, the <a href="/wiki/Florence_Nightingale_Faculty_of_Nursing_and_Midwifery" title="Florence Nightingale Faculty of Nursing and Midwifery">first nursing school</a> is now part of King's College London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[413]</a></sup> There are a number of business schools in London, including the <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Business_and_Finance" title="London School of Business and Finance">London School of Business and Finance</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cass_Business_School" title="Cass Business School">Cass Business School</a> (part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_University_London" title="City University London">City University London</a>), <a href="/wiki/Hult_International_Business_School" title="Hult International Business School">Hult International Business School</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ESCP_Europe" title="ESCP Europe">ESCP Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Business_School_London" title="European Business School London">European Business School London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_Business_School" title="Imperial College Business School">Imperial College Business School</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_Business_School" title="London Business School">London Business School</a> and the <a href="/wiki/UCL_School_of_Management" title="UCL School of Management">UCL School of Management</a>. 
</p><p>London is also home to many specialist arts education institutions, including the <a href="/wiki/Central_School_of_Ballet" title="Central School of Ballet">Central School of Ballet</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Academy_of_Music_and_Dramatic_Art" title="London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art">London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art</a> (LAMDA; president <a href="/wiki/Benedict_Cumberbatch" title="Benedict Cumberbatch">Benedict Cumberbatch</a>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_College_of_Contemporary_Arts" title="London College of Contemporary Arts">London College of Contemporary Arts</a> (LCCA), <a href="/wiki/London_Contemporary_Dance_School" title="London Contemporary Dance School">London Contemporary Dance School</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Circus_Space" title="The Circus Space">National Centre for Circus Arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art" title="Royal Academy of Dramatic Art">Royal Academy of Dramatic Art</a> (RADA; president Sir <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Branagh" title="Kenneth Branagh">Kenneth Branagh</a>), <a href="/wiki/Rambert_Dance_Company" title="Rambert Dance Company">Rambert School of Ballet and Contemporary Dance</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art" title="Royal College of Art">Royal College of Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sylvia_Young_Theatre_School" title="Sylvia Young Theatre School">Sylvia Young Theatre School</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trinity_Laban" title="Trinity Laban">Trinity Laban</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[415]</a></sup> Located in the London borough of Croydon, the <a href="/wiki/BRIT_School" title="BRIT School">BRIT School</a> provides training for the performing arts and the technologies that make performance possible, with actor <a href="/wiki/Tom_Holland" title="Tom Holland">Tom Holland</a> among their alumni.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[416]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary_and_secondary_education">Primary and secondary education</span></h3>
<p>The majority of primary and secondary schools and further-education colleges in London are controlled by the <a href="/wiki/London_boroughs" title="London boroughs">London boroughs</a> or otherwise state-funded; leading examples include <a href="/wiki/Ashbourne_College" title="Ashbourne College">Ashbourne College</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bethnal_Green_Academy" title="Bethnal Green Academy">Bethnal Green Academy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brampton_Manor_Academy" title="Brampton Manor Academy">Brampton Manor Academy</a>, <a href="/wiki/City_and_Islington_College" title="City and Islington College">City and Islington College</a>, <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster_College" title="City of Westminster College">City of Westminster College</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Game_College" title="David Game College">David Game College</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ealing,_Hammersmith_and_West_London_College" title="Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College">Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leyton_Sixth_Form_College" title="Leyton Sixth Form College">Leyton Sixth Form College</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Academy_of_Excellence" title="London Academy of Excellence">London Academy of Excellence</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tower_Hamlets_College" title="Tower Hamlets College">Tower Hamlets College</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Newham_Collegiate_Sixth_Form_Centre" title="Newham Collegiate Sixth Form Centre">Newham Collegiate Sixth Form Centre</a>. There are also a number of private schools and colleges in London, some old and famous, such as <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_School" title="City of London School">City of London School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harrow_School" title="Harrow School">Harrow</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_School_(London)" title="St Paul's School (London)">St Paul's School</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haberdashers%27_Aske%27s_Boys%27_School" title="Haberdashers' Aske's Boys' School">Haberdashers' Aske's Boys' School</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_College_School" title="University College School">University College School</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_John_Lyon_School" title="The John Lyon School">The John Lyon School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Highgate_School" title="Highgate School">Highgate School</a> and <a href="/wiki/Westminster_School" title="Westminster School">Westminster School</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Societies">Societies</span></h3>
<p>Important scientific <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Learned_societies" title="Learned societies">learned societies</a> based in London include the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society" title="Royal Society">Royal Society</a>—the UK's national <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_sciences" title="Academy of sciences">academy of sciences</a> and the oldest national scientific institution in the world—founded in 1660,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[417]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Institution" title="Royal Institution">Royal Institution</a>, founded in 1799; the basement of the latter is where <a href="/wiki/Michael_Faraday" title="Michael Faraday">Michael Faraday</a> first demonstrated <a href="/wiki/Electric_motor" title="Electric motor">electric motion</a> in 1821.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[418]</a></sup> Since 1825, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Institution_Christmas_Lectures" title="Royal Institution Christmas Lectures">Royal Institution Christmas Lectures</a> have presented scientific subjects to a general audience, and speakers have included aerospace engineer <a href="/wiki/Frank_Whittle" title="Frank Whittle">Frank Whittle</a>, naturalist <a href="/wiki/David_Attenborough" title="David Attenborough">David Attenborough</a> and evolutionary biologist <a href="/wiki/Richard_Dawkins" title="Richard Dawkins">Richard Dawkins</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[419]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_London" title="Culture of London">Culture of London</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Leisure_and_entertainment">Leisure and entertainment</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_annual_events_in_London" title="List of annual events in London">List of annual events in London</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End theatre</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Open_Happiness_Piccadilly_Circus_Blue-Pink_Hour_120917-1126-jikatu.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3564" data-file-width="5366" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Open_Happiness_Piccadilly_Circus_Blue-Pink_Hour_120917-1126-jikatu.jpg/200px-Open_Happiness_Piccadilly_Circus_Blue-Pink_Hour_120917-1126-jikatu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Open_Happiness_Piccadilly_Circus_Blue-Pink_Hour_120917-1126-jikatu.jpg/300px-Open_Happiness_Piccadilly_Circus_Blue-Pink_Hour_120917-1126-jikatu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Open_Happiness_Piccadilly_Circus_Blue-Pink_Hour_120917-1126-jikatu.jpg/400px-Open_Happiness_Piccadilly_Circus_Blue-Pink_Hour_120917-1126-jikatu.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Open_Happiness_Piccadilly_Circus_Blue-Pink_Hour_120917-1126-jikatu.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Piccadilly_Circus" title="Piccadilly Circus">Piccadilly Circus</a></div></div></div>
<p>Leisure is a major part of the London economy. A 2003 report attributed a quarter of the entire UK leisure economy to London<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[420]</a></sup> at 25.6 events per 1000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[421]</a></sup> The city is one of the four <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion capitals</a> of the world, and, according to official statistics, is the world's third-busiest film production centre, presents more live comedy than any other city,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[422]</a></sup> and has the biggest theatre audience of any city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[423]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Harrods_at_Night,_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3500" data-file-width="2948" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg/150px-Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg/225px-Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg/300px-Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Harrods_at_Night,_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Harrods" title="Harrods">Harrods</a> in <a href="/wiki/Knightsbridge" title="Knightsbridge">Knightsbridge</a></div></div></div>
<p>Within the <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster" title="City of Westminster">City of Westminster</a> in London, the entertainment district of the <a href="/wiki/West_End_of_London" title="West End of London">West End</a> has its focus around <a href="/wiki/Leicester_Square" title="Leicester Square">Leicester Square</a>, where London and world film <a href="/wiki/Premiere" title="Premiere">premieres</a> are held, and <a href="/wiki/Piccadilly_Circus" title="Piccadilly Circus">Piccadilly Circus</a>, with its giant electronic advertisements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_160_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_160-432">[424]</a></sup> London's <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">theatre district</a> is here, as are many cinemas, bars, clubs, and restaurants, including the city's <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_London" title="Chinatown, London">Chinatown</a> district (in <a href="/wiki/Soho" title="Soho">Soho</a>), and just to the east is <a href="/wiki/Royal_Opera_House" title="Royal Opera House">Covent Garden</a>, an area housing speciality shops. The city is the home of <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber" title="Andrew Lloyd Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a>, whose musicals have dominated West End theatre since the late 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[425]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Agatha_Christie" title="Agatha Christie">Agatha Christie</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mousetrap" title="The Mousetrap">The Mousetrap</a></i>, the world's longest-running play, has been performed in the West End since 1952.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[426]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier_Awards" title="Laurence Olivier Awards">Laurence Olivier Awards</a>–named after <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier" title="Laurence Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a>–are given annually by the <a href="/wiki/Society_of_London_Theatre" title="Society of London Theatre">Society of London Theatre</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Ballet" title="Royal Ballet">Royal Ballet</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_National_Ballet" title="English National Ballet">English National Ballet</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Opera,_London" title="Royal Opera, London">Royal Opera</a>, and <a href="/wiki/English_National_Opera" title="English National Opera">English National Opera</a> are based in London and perform at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Opera_House" title="Royal Opera House">Royal Opera House</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_Coliseum" title="London Coliseum">London Coliseum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sadler%27s_Wells_Theatre" title="Sadler's Wells Theatre">Sadler's Wells Theatre</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a>, as well as touring the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London's_Concerts_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-London's_Concerts-435">[427]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Notting_Hill_Carnival_2014_(1).JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="3891" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Notting_Hill_Carnival_2014_%281%29.JPG/200px-Notting_Hill_Carnival_2014_%281%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Notting_Hill_Carnival_2014_%281%29.JPG/300px-Notting_Hill_Carnival_2014_%281%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Notting_Hill_Carnival_2014_%281%29.JPG/400px-Notting_Hill_Carnival_2014_%281%29.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Notting_Hill_Carnival_2014_(1).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Scene of the annual <a href="/wiki/Notting_Hill_Carnival" title="Notting Hill Carnival">Notting Hill Carnival</a>, 2014</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Islington" title="Islington">Islington</a>'s 1 mile (1.6 km) long Upper Street, extending northwards from <a href="/wiki/Angel,_London" title="Angel, London">Angel</a>, has more bars and restaurants than any other street in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_161_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_161-436">[428]</a></sup> Europe's busiest shopping area is <a href="/wiki/Oxford_Street" title="Oxford Street">Oxford Street</a>, a shopping street nearly 1 mile (1.6 km) long, making it the longest shopping street in the UK. It is home to vast numbers of retailers and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_stores" title="Department stores">department stores</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Selfridges" title="Selfridges">Selfridges</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flagship_store#Retailing" title="Flagship store">flagship store</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_162_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_162-437">[429]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Knightsbridge" title="Knightsbridge">Knightsbridge</a>, home to the equally renowned <a href="/wiki/Harrods" title="Harrods">Harrods</a> department store, lies to the south-west. Opened in 1760 with its flagship store on <a href="/wiki/Regent_Street" title="Regent Street">Regent Street</a> since 1881, <a href="/wiki/Hamleys" title="Hamleys">Hamleys</a> is the oldest <a href="/wiki/Toy_store" title="Toy store">toy store</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[430]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Madame_Tussauds" title="Madame Tussauds">Madame Tussauds</a> wax museum opened in <a href="/wiki/Baker_Street" title="Baker Street">Baker Street</a> in 1835.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[431]</a></sup>
</p><p>London is home to designers <a href="/wiki/Vivienne_Westwood" title="Vivienne Westwood">Vivienne Westwood</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Galliano" title="John Galliano">Galliano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stella_McCartney" title="Stella McCartney">Stella McCartney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manolo_Blahnik" title="Manolo Blahnik">Manolo Blahnik</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Choo" title="Jimmy Choo">Jimmy Choo</a>, among others; its renowned art and fashion schools make it one of the four international centres of fashion. <a href="/wiki/Mary_Quant" title="Mary Quant">Mary Quant</a> designed the <a href="/wiki/Miniskirt" title="Miniskirt">miniskirt</a> in her <a href="/wiki/King%27s_Road" title="King's Road">King's Road</a> boutique in <a href="/wiki/Swinging_Sixties" title="Swinging Sixties">Swinging Sixties London</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[432]</a></sup> London offers a great variety of cuisine as a result of its ethnically diverse population.
