Gastronomic centres include the Bangladeshi restaurants of <a href="/wiki/Brick_Lane" title="Brick Lane">Brick Lane</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_food" title="Chinese food">Chinese</a> restaurants of <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_London" title="Chinatown, London">Chinatown</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_163_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_163-441">[433]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_takeaway" title="Chinese takeaway">Chinese takeaways</a> are located throughout London, as are Indian restaurants which provide <a href="/wiki/English_cuisine#Indian_and_Anglo-Indian_cuisine" title="English cuisine">Indian and Anglo-Indian cuisine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[434]</a></sup> Around 1860, the first <a href="/wiki/Fish_and_chips" title="Fish and chips">fish and chips</a> shop in London was opened by Joseph Malin, a Jewish immigrant, in <a href="/wiki/Bow,_London" title="Bow, London">Bow</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London_traditions_395-1"><a href="#cite_note-London_traditions-395">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[435]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Full_English_breakfast" title="Full English breakfast">full English breakfast</a> dates from the Victorian era, and many <a href="/wiki/Cafe_(British)" title="Cafe (British)">cafe</a>'s in London serve a full English throughout the day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[436]</a></sup> London has five 3-Michelin star restaurants, including <a href="/wiki/Restaurant_Gordon_Ramsay" title="Restaurant Gordon Ramsay">Restaurant Gordon Ramsay</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chelsea,_London" title="Chelsea, London">Chelsea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[437]</a></sup> Many hotels in London provide a traditional <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afternoon_tea" title="Afternoon tea">afternoon tea</a> service, such as the <a href="/wiki/Hotel_Caf%C3%A9_Royal#Restoration_and_conversion" title="Hotel Café Royal">Oscar Wilde Lounge</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Hotel_Caf%C3%A9_Royal" title="Hotel Café Royal">Hotel Café Royal</a> in Piccadilly, and a themed tea service is also available, for example an <i><a href="/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland" title="Alice's Adventures in Wonderland">Alice in Wonderland</a></i> themed afternoon tea served at the <a href="/wiki/Egerton_House_Hotel" title="Egerton House Hotel">Egerton House Hotel</a>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Charlie_and_the_Chocolate_Factory" title="Charlie and the Chocolate Factory">Charlie and the Chocolate Factory</a></i> themed afternoon tea at <a href="/wiki/One_Aldwych" title="One Aldwych">One Aldwych</a> in Covent Garden.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[440]</a></sup> The nation's most popular <a href="/wiki/Biscuit" title="Biscuit">biscuit</a> to <a href="/wiki/Dunking_(biscuit)" title="Dunking (biscuit)">dunk</a> in tea, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chocolate_digestive" title="Chocolate digestive">chocolate digestives</a> have been manufactured by <a href="/wiki/McVitie%27s" title="McVitie's">McVitie's</a> at their <a href="/wiki/Harlesden" title="Harlesden">Harlesden</a> factory in north-west London since 1925.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[441]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Restaurante_The_Swan,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-11,_DD_113.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3212" data-file-width="4073" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg/220px-Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg/330px-Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg/440px-Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Restaurante_The_Swan,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-11,_DD_113.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shakespeare%27s_Globe" title="Shakespeare's Globe">Shakespeare's Globe</a> is a modern reconstruction of the Globe Theatre on the south bank of the Thames.</div></div></div>
<p>There is a variety of <a href="/wiki/List_of_annual_events_in_London" title="List of annual events in London">annual events</a>, beginning with the relatively new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Year%27s_Day_Parade" title="New Year's Day Parade">New Year's Day Parade</a>, a fireworks display at the <a href="/wiki/London_Eye" title="London Eye">London Eye</a>; the world's second largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Street_party" title="Street party">street party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Notting_Hill_Carnival" title="Notting Hill Carnival">Notting Hill Carnival</a>, is held on the late <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/August_Bank_Holiday" title="August Bank Holiday">August Bank Holiday</a> each year. Traditional parades include November's <a href="/wiki/Lord_Mayor%27s_Show" title="Lord Mayor's Show">Lord Mayor's Show</a>, a centuries-old event celebrating the annual appointment of a new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_the_City_of_London" title="Lord Mayor of the City of London">Lord Mayor of the City of London</a> with a procession along the streets of the city, and June's <a href="/wiki/Trooping_the_Colour" title="Trooping the Colour">Trooping the Colour</a>, a formal military pageant performed by regiments of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British</a> armies to celebrate the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen%27s_Official_Birthday" title="Queen's Official Birthday">Queen's Official Birthday</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_164_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_164-450">[442]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Boishakhi_Mela" title="Boishakhi Mela">Boishakhi Mela</a> is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_New_Year" title="Bengali New Year">Bengali New Year</a> festival celebrated by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Bangladeshi" title="British Bangladeshi">British Bangladeshi</a> community. It is the largest open-air Asian festival in Europe. After the Notting Hill Carnival, it is the second-largest street festival in the United Kingdom attracting over 80,000 visitors from across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[443]</a></sup> First held in 1862, the <a href="/wiki/Chelsea_Flower_Show" title="Chelsea Flower Show">RHS Chelsea Flower Show</a> (run by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Horticultural_Society" title="Royal Horticultural Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a>) takes place over five days in May every year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[444]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="LGBT_scene">LGBT scene</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1280" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg/170px-Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg/255px-Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg/340px-Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Comptons_of_Soho" title="Comptons of Soho">Comptons of Soho</a> during <a href="/wiki/Pride_in_London" title="Pride in London">London Pride</a> in 2010</div></div></div>
<p>The first <a href="/wiki/Gay_bar" title="Gay bar">gay bar</a> in London in the modern sense was <a href="/wiki/The_Cave_of_the_Golden_Calf" title="The Cave of the Golden Calf">The Cave of the Golden Calf</a>, established as a night club in an underground location at 9 Heddon Street, just off <a href="/wiki/Regent_Street" title="Regent Street">Regent Street</a>, in 1912 and became a haunt for the wealthy, aristocratic and bohemian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[445]</a></sup> While London has been an LGBT tourism destination, after <a href="/wiki/Sexual_Offences_Act_1967" title="Sexual Offences Act 1967">homosexuality was decriminalized</a> in England in 1967 gay bar culture became more visible, and from the early 1970s <a href="/wiki/Soho" title="Soho">Soho</a> (and in particular <a href="/wiki/Old_Compton_Street" title="Old Compton Street">Old Compton Street</a>) became the centre of the <a href="/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_London" title="LGBT culture in London">London LGBT community</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olson_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-Olson-454">[446]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/G-A-Y" title="G-A-Y">G-A-Y</a>, previously based at the <a href="/wiki/London_Astoria" title="London Astoria">Astoria</a>, and now <a href="/wiki/Heaven_(nightclub)" title="Heaven (nightclub)">Heaven</a>, is a long-running night club.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[447]</a></sup>
</p><p>Wider British cultural movements have also influenced LGBT culture: for example, the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Glam_rock" title="Glam rock">glam rock</a> in the UK in the early 1970s, via <a href="/wiki/Marc_Bolan" title="Marc Bolan">Marc Bolan</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Bowie" title="David Bowie">David Bowie</a>, saw a generation of teenagers begin playing with the idea of androgyny, and the West End musical <i><a href="/wiki/The_Rocky_Horror_Show" title="The Rocky Horror Show">The Rocky Horror Show</a></i>, which debuted in London in 1973, is also widely said to have been an influence on countercultural and sexual liberation movements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[448]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Blitz_Kids" title="Blitz Kids">Blitz Kids</a> (which included <a href="/wiki/Boy_George" title="Boy George">Boy George</a>) frequented the Tuesday club-night at Blitz in <a href="/wiki/Covent_Garden" title="Covent Garden">Covent Garden</a>, helping launch the <a href="/wiki/New_Romantic" title="New Romantic">New Romantic</a> subcultural movement in the late 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[449]</a></sup> Today, the annual <a href="/wiki/Pride_in_London" title="Pride in London">London Pride Parade</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Lesbian_and_Gay_Film_Festival" title="London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival">London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival</a> are held in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olson_454-1"><a href="#cite_note-Olson-454">[446]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Literature.2C_film_and_television"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature,_film_and_television">Literature, film and television</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/London_in_fiction" title="London in fiction">London in fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_in_film" title="London in film">London in film</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_television_shows_set_in_London" title="List of television shows set in London">List of television shows set in London</a>, and <a href="/wiki/London_Television_Archive" title="London Television Archive">London Television Archive</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg/220px-Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg/330px-Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg/440px-Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum" title="Sherlock Holmes Museum">Sherlock Holmes Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Baker_Street" title="Baker Street">Baker Street</a>, bearing the number 221B</div></div></div>
<p>London has been the setting for many works of literature. The pilgrims in <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer" title="Geoffrey Chaucer">Geoffrey Chaucer</a>'s late 14th-century <i><a href="/wiki/The_Canterbury_Tales" title="The Canterbury Tales">Canterbury Tales</a></i> set out for <a href="/wiki/Canterbury" title="Canterbury">Canterbury</a> from London—specifically, from the <a href="/wiki/The_Tabard" title="The Tabard">Tabard</a> inn, <a href="/wiki/Southwark" title="Southwark">Southwark</a>. <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> spent a large part of his life living and working in London; his contemporary <a href="/wiki/Ben_Jonson" title="Ben Jonson">Ben Jonson</a> was also based there, and some of his work, most notably his play <i><a href="/wiki/The_Alchemist_(play)" title="The Alchemist (play)">The Alchemist</a></i>, was set in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London_in_Literature_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-London_in_Literature-458">[450]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/A_Journal_of_the_Plague_Year" title="A Journal of the Plague Year">A Journal of the Plague Year</a></i> (1722) by <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Defoe" title="Daniel Defoe">Daniel Defoe</a> is a fictionalisation of the events of the 1665 <a href="/wiki/Great_Plague_of_London" title="Great Plague of London">Great Plague</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London_in_Literature_458-1"><a href="#cite_note-London_in_Literature-458">[450]</a></sup>
</p><p>The literary centres of London have traditionally been hilly <a href="/wiki/Hampstead" title="Hampstead">Hampstead</a> and (since the early 20th century) <a href="/wiki/Bloomsbury" title="Bloomsbury">Bloomsbury</a>. Writers closely associated with the city are the diarist <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Pepys" title="Samuel Pepys">Samuel Pepys</a>, noted for his eyewitness account of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire</a>; <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a>, whose representation of a foggy, snowy, grimy London of street sweepers and pickpockets has been a major influence on people's vision of early <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian</a> London; and <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Woolf" title="Virginia Woolf">Virginia Woolf</a>, regarded as one of the foremost <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modernist_literature" title="Modernist literature">modernist</a> literary figures of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London_in_Literature_458-2"><a href="#cite_note-London_in_Literature-458">[450]</a></sup> Later important depictions of London from the 19th and early 20th centuries are <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle" title="Arthur Conan Doyle">Arthur Conan Doyle</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a> stories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London_in_Literature_458-3"><a href="#cite_note-London_in_Literature-458">[450]</a></sup> In 1898, <a href="/wiki/H._G._Wells" title="H. G. Wells">H. G. Wells</a>' sci-fi novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_War_of_the_Worlds" title="The War of the Worlds">The War of the Worlds</a></i> sees London (and the south of England) invaded by Martians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[451]</a></sup> Also of significance is <a href="/wiki/Letitia_Elizabeth_Landon" title="Letitia Elizabeth Landon">Letitia Elizabeth Landon</a>'s <i>Calendar of the London Seasons</i> (1834). Modern writers pervasively influenced by the city include <a href="/wiki/Peter_Ackroyd" title="Peter Ackroyd">Peter Ackroyd</a>, author of a "biography" of London, and <a href="/wiki/Iain_Sinclair" title="Iain Sinclair">Iain Sinclair</a>, who writes in the genre of <a href="/wiki/Psychogeography" title="Psychogeography">psychogeography</a>. In the 1940s, <a href="/wiki/George_Orwell" title="George Orwell">George Orwell</a> wrote essays in the <i><a href="/wiki/Evening_Standard" title="Evening Standard">London Evening Standard</a></i>, most notably "<a href="/wiki/A_Nice_Cup_of_Tea" title="A Nice Cup of Tea">A Nice Cup of Tea</a>", which concerned the nation's methods on <a href="/wiki/Tea_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Tea in the United Kingdom">making tea</a>, and "<a href="/wiki/The_Moon_Under_Water" title="The Moon Under Water">The Moon Under Water</a>", which provided a detailed description of his ideal <a href="/wiki/Pub" title="Pub">pub</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[452]</a></sup> In 1958, author <a href="/wiki/Michael_Bond" title="Michael Bond">Michael Bond</a> created <a href="/wiki/Paddington_Bear" title="Paddington Bear">Paddington Bear</a>, a refugee found in <a href="/wiki/London_Paddington_station" title="London Paddington station">London Paddington station</a> by the Brown family who adopt him. Paddington has been adapted for the screen, including <i><a href="/wiki/Paddington_(film)" title="Paddington (film)">Paddington</a></i> (2014) which features the calypso song "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_is_the_Place_for_Me" title="London is the Place for Me">London is the Place for Me</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[453]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097025294">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-right plainlinks sistersitebox">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/57px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/76px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" width="38"/></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a> has original text related to this article:
<div style="margin-left: 10px;"><b><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Calendar_of_the_London_Seasons/Calendar_of_the_London_Seasons" title="wikisource:Calendar of the London Seasons/Calendar of the London Seasons">'Calendar of the London Seasons', by L. E. L.</a></b></div></div></div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_July_2010_(4818942309).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg/220px-London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg/330px-London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg/440px-London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:London_July_2010_(4818942309).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Opened in 1937, the <a href="/wiki/Odeon_Luxe_Leicester_Square" title="Odeon Luxe Leicester Square">Odeon cinema</a> in <a href="/wiki/Leicester_Square" title="Leicester Square">Leicester Square</a> hosts numerous European and world film premieres.</div></div></div>
<p>London has played a significant role in the film industry. Major studios within or bordering London include <a href="/wiki/Pinewood_Studios" title="Pinewood Studios">Pinewood</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elstree_Studios" title="Elstree Studios">Elstree</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ealing_Studios" title="Ealing Studios">Ealing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shepperton_Studios" title="Shepperton Studios">Shepperton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Twickenham_Studios" title="Twickenham Studios">Twickenham</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Studios,_Leavesden" title="Warner Bros. Studios, Leavesden">Leavesden</a>, with the <i><a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)" title="Harry Potter (film series)">Harry Potter</a></i> series among many notable films produced here.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[454]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-filmlondon_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-filmlondon-463">[455]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Working_Title_Films" title="Working Title Films">Working Title Films</a> has its headquarters in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_165_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_165-464">[456]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Post-production" title="Post-production">post-production</a> community is centred in <a href="/wiki/Soho" title="Soho">Soho</a>, and London houses six of the world’s largest <a href="/wiki/Visual_effects" title="Visual effects">visual effects</a> companies, such as <a href="/wiki/Framestore" title="Framestore">Framestore</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[457]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Imaginarium" title="The Imaginarium">The Imaginarium</a>, a digital performance-capture studio, was founded by <a href="/wiki/Andy_Serkis" title="Andy Serkis">Andy Serkis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[458]</a></sup> London has been the setting for films including <i><a href="/wiki/Oliver_Twist_(1948_film)" title="Oliver Twist (1948 film)">Oliver Twist</a></i> (1948), <i><a href="/wiki/Scrooge_(1951_film)" title="Scrooge (1951 film)">Scrooge</a></i> (1951), <i><a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan_(1953_film)" title="Peter Pan (1953 film)">Peter Pan</a></i> (1953), <i><a href="/wiki/101_Dalmatians_(1996_film)" title="101 Dalmatians (1996 film)">The 101 Dalmatians</a></i> (1961), <i><a href="/wiki/My_Fair_Lady_(film)" title="My Fair Lady (film)">My Fair Lady</a></i> (1964), <i><a href="/wiki/Mary_Poppins_(film)" title="Mary Poppins (film)">Mary Poppins</a></i> (1964), <i><a href="/wiki/Blowup" title="Blowup">Blowup</a></i> (1966), <i><a href="/wiki/A_Clockwork_Orange_(film)" title="A Clockwork Orange (film)">A Clockwork Orange</a></i> (1971), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Long_Good_Friday" title="The Long Good Friday">The Long Good Friday</a></i> (1980), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Great_Mouse_Detective" title="The Great Mouse Detective">The Great Mouse Detective</a></i> (1986), <i><a href="/wiki/Notting_Hill_(film)" title="Notting Hill (film)">Notting Hill</a></i> (1999), <i><a href="/wiki/Love_Actually" title="Love Actually">Love Actually</a></i> (2003), <i><a href="/wiki/V_for_Vendetta_(film)" title="V for Vendetta (film)">V for Vendetta</a></i> (2005), <i><a href="/wiki/Sweeney_Todd:_The_Demon_Barber_of_Fleet_Street" title="Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street">Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street</a></i> (2008) and <i><a href="/wiki/The_King%27s_Speech" title="The King's Speech">The King's Speech</a></i> (2010). Notable actors and filmmakers from London include; <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin" title="Charlie Chaplin">Charlie Chaplin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Caine" title="Michael Caine">Michael Caine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emma_Thompson" title="Emma Thompson">Emma Thompson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gary_Oldman" title="Gary Oldman">Gary Oldman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guy_Ritchie" title="Guy Ritchie">Guy Ritchie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Nolan" title="Christopher Nolan">Christopher Nolan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Rickman" title="Alan Rickman">Alan Rickman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jude_Law" title="Jude Law">Jude Law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter" title="Helena Bonham Carter">Helena Bonham Carter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Idris_Elba" title="Idris Elba">Idris Elba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Hardy" title="Tom Hardy">Tom Hardy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Keira_Knightley" title="Keira Knightley">Keira Knightley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ealing_comedies" title="Ealing comedies">Ealing comedies</a> have featured <a href="/wiki/Alec_Guinness" title="Alec Guinness">Alec Guinness</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hammer_Film_Productions" title="Hammer Film Productions">Hammer Horrors</a> have starred <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Lee" title="Christopher Lee">Christopher Lee</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Richard_Curtis" title="Richard Curtis">Richard Curtis</a>'s rom-coms have featured <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Grant" title="Hugh Grant">Hugh Grant</a>. The largest cinema chain in the country, <a href="/wiki/Odeon_Cinemas" title="Odeon Cinemas">Odeon Cinemas</a> was founded in London in 1928 by <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Deutsch" title="Oscar Deutsch">Oscar Deutsch</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[459]</a></sup> First held in 1949, since 2017 the <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="British Academy Film Awards">British Academy Film Awards</a> (BAFTAs) have taken place at the Royal Albert Hall. Founded in 1957, the <a href="/wiki/BFI_London_Film_Festival" title="BFI London Film Festival">BFI London Film Festival</a> takes place over two weeks every October.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[460]</a></sup>
</p><p>London is a major centre for television production, with studios including <a href="/wiki/Television_Centre,_London" title="Television Centre, London">Television Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/ITV_Studios" title="ITV Studios">ITV Studios</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sky_Campus" title="Sky Campus">Sky Campus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fountain_Studios" title="Fountain Studios">Fountain Studios</a>; the latter hosted the original talent shows, <i><a href="/wiki/Pop_Idol" title="Pop Idol">Pop Idol</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_X_Factor_(British_TV_series)" title="The X Factor (British TV series)">The X Factor</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Britain%27s_Got_Talent" title="Britain's Got Talent">Britain's Got Talent</a></i>, before each format was exported around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[461]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[462]</a></sup> Formerly a franchise of ITV, <a href="/wiki/Thames_Television" title="Thames Television">Thames Television</a> featured comedians such as <a href="/wiki/Benny_Hill" title="Benny Hill">Benny Hill</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rowan_Atkinson" title="Rowan Atkinson">Rowan Atkinson</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Mr._Bean" title="Mr. Bean">Mr. Bean</a></i> was first screened by Thames), while <a href="/wiki/Talkback_(production_company)" title="Talkback (production company)">Talkback</a> produced <i><a href="/wiki/Da_Ali_G_Show" title="Da Ali G Show">Da Ali G Show</a></i> which featured <a href="/wiki/Sacha_Baron_Cohen" title="Sacha Baron Cohen">Sacha Baron Cohen</a> as <a href="/wiki/Ali_G" title="Ali G">Ali G</a>, a faux-streetwise gangster from <a href="/wiki/Staines-upon-Thames" title="Staines-upon-Thames">Staines</a>, west of London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[463]</a></sup> Many television shows have been set in London, including the popular television soap opera <i><a href="/wiki/EastEnders" title="EastEnders">EastEnders</a></i>, broadcast by the BBC since 1985.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[464]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Museums.2C_art_galleries_and_libraries"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums,_art_galleries_and_libraries">Museums, art galleries and libraries</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1749" data-file-width="2513" decoding="async" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg/310px-Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg/465px-Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg/620px-Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Aerial view of <a href="/wiki/Albertopolis" title="Albertopolis">Albertopolis</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Albert_Memorial" title="Albert Memorial">Albert Memorial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Geographical_Society" title="Royal Geographical Society">Royal Geographical Society</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art" title="Royal College of Art">Royal College of Art</a> are visible near the top; <a href="/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum" title="Victoria and Albert Museum">Victoria and Albert Museum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London" title="Natural History Museum, London">Natural History Museum</a> at the lower end; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperial_College" title="Imperial College">Imperial College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music" title="Royal College of Music">Royal College of Music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Science_Museum,_London" title="Science Museum, London">Science Museum</a> lying in between.</div></div></div>
<p>London is <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_London" title="List of museums in London">home to many museums</a>, galleries, and other institutions, many of which are free of admission charges and are major <a href="/wiki/Tourist_attraction" title="Tourist attraction">tourist attractions</a> as well as playing a research role. The first of these to be established was the <a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bloomsbury" title="Bloomsbury">Bloomsbury</a>, in 1753.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[465]</a></sup> Originally containing antiquities, natural history specimens, and the national library, the museum now has 7 million artefacts from around the globe. In 1824, the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a> was founded to house the British national collection of Western paintings; this now occupies a prominent position in <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[466]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/British_Library" title="British Library">British Library</a> is the second <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_libraries" title="List of largest libraries">largest library in the world</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/National_library" title="National library">national library</a> of the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[467]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[468]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[469]</a></sup> There are many other research libraries, including the <a href="/wiki/Wellcome_Library" title="Wellcome Library">Wellcome Library</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dana_Library_and_Research_Centre" title="Dana Library and Research Centre">Dana Centre</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Academic_library" title="Academic library">university libraries</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/British_Library_of_Political_and_Economic_Science" title="British Library of Political and Economic Science">British Library of Political and Economic Science</a> at <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Economics" title="London School of Economics">LSE</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_Central_Library" title="Imperial College Central Library">Central Library</a> at <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maughan_Library" title="Maughan Library">Maughan Library</a> at <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London" title="King's College London">King's</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Senate_House_Libraries" title="Senate House Libraries">Senate House Libraries</a> at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_London" title="University of London">University of London</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[470]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[471]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the latter half of the 19th century the locale of <a href="/wiki/South_Kensington" title="South Kensington">South Kensington</a> was developed as "<a href="/wiki/Albertopolis" title="Albertopolis">Albertopolis</a>", a cultural and scientific quarter. Three major national museums are there: the <a href="/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum" title="Victoria and Albert Museum">Victoria and Albert Museum</a> (for the <a href="/wiki/Applied_arts" title="Applied arts">applied arts</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London" title="Natural History Museum, London">Natural History Museum</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Science_Museum" title="London Science Museum">Science Museum</a>. The <a href="/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery,_London" title="National Portrait Gallery, London">National Portrait Gallery</a> was founded in 1856 to house depictions of figures from British history; its holdings now comprise the world's most extensive collection of portraits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[472]</a></sup> The national gallery of British art is at <a href="/wiki/Tate_Britain" title="Tate Britain">Tate Britain</a>, originally established as an annexe of the National Gallery in 1897. The Tate Gallery, as it was formerly known, also became a major centre for modern art. In 2000, this collection moved to <a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a>, a new gallery housed in the former <a href="/wiki/Bankside_Power_Station" title="Bankside Power Station">Bankside Power Station</a> which is accessed by pedestrians north of the Thames via the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Bridge,_London" title="Millennium Bridge, London">Millennium Bridge</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[473]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG/220px-Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG/330px-Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG/440px-Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Albert_Hall.001_-_London.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> hosts concerts and musical events, including <a href="/wiki/BBC_Proms" title="BBC Proms">The Proms</a> which are held every summer, as well as cinema screenings of films accompanied with live orchestral music.</div></div></div>
<p>London is one of the major classical and <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">popular music</a> capitals of the world and hosts major music corporations, such as <a href="/wiki/Universal_Music_Group" title="Universal Music Group">Universal Music Group International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Warner_Music_Group" title="Warner Music Group">Warner Music Group</a>, and countless bands, musicians and industry professionals. The city is also home to many orchestras and concert halls, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barbican_Arts_Centre" title="Barbican Arts Centre">Barbican Arts Centre</a> (principal base of the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra" title="London Symphony Orchestra">London Symphony Orchestra</a> and the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Chorus" title="London Symphony Chorus">London Symphony Chorus</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Southbank_Centre" title="Southbank Centre">Southbank Centre</a> (<a href="/wiki/London_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="London Philharmonic Orchestra">London Philharmonic Orchestra</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Philharmonia_Orchestra" title="Philharmonia Orchestra">Philharmonia Orchestra</a>), <a href="/wiki/Cadogan_Hall" title="Cadogan Hall">Cadogan Hall</a> (<a href="/wiki/Royal_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Royal Philharmonic Orchestra">Royal Philharmonic Orchestra</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Proms" title="The Proms">The Proms</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London's_Concerts_435-1"><a href="#cite_note-London's_Concerts-435">[427]</a></sup> The Proms, an eight-week summer season of daily orchestral classical music first held in 1895, ends with the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Proms#Last_Night_of_the_Proms" title="BBC Proms">Last Night of the Proms</a> (works by <a href="/wiki/Edward_Elgar" title="Edward Elgar">Edward Elgar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Wood" title="Henry Wood">Henry Wood</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Arne" title="Thomas Arne">Thomas Arne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Parry" title="Hubert Parry">Hubert Parry</a> feature at the climax). London's two main opera houses are the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Opera_House" title="Royal Opera House">Royal Opera House</a> and the <a href="/wiki/London_Coliseum" title="London Coliseum">London Coliseum</a> (home to the <a href="/wiki/English_National_Opera" title="English National Opera">English National Opera</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London's_Concerts_435-2"><a href="#cite_note-London's_Concerts-435">[427]</a></sup> The UK's largest <a href="/wiki/Pipe_organ" title="Pipe organ">pipe organ</a> is at the Royal Albert Hall. Other significant instruments are in cathedrals and major churches—the church bells of <a href="/wiki/St_Clement_Danes" title="St Clement Danes">St Clement Danes</a> feature in the 1744 <a href="/wiki/Nursery_rhyme" title="Nursery rhyme">nursery rhyme</a> "<a href="/wiki/Oranges_and_Lemons" title="Oranges and Lemons">Oranges and Lemons</a>", and the lyrics journey through churches and bells of 18th century London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[474]</a></sup> Several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conservatoire" title="Conservatoire">conservatoires</a> are within the city: <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music" title="Royal Academy of Music">Royal Academy of Music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music" title="Royal College of Music">Royal College of Music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guildhall_School_of_Music_and_Drama" title="Guildhall School of Music and Drama">Guildhall School of Music and Drama</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trinity_College_of_Music" title="Trinity College of Music">Trinity Laban</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="3200" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg/220px-Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg/330px-Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg/440px-Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios" title="Abbey Road Studios">Abbey Road Studios</a> was given <a href="/wiki/Listed_building#Grade_II" title="Listed building">grade II listed</a> status for its "cultural and historical importance" in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[475]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>London has numerous venues for rock and pop concerts, including the world's busiest indoor venue, <a href="/wiki/The_O2_Arena" title="The O2 Arena">the O<sub>2</sub> Arena</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[476]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Arena" title="Wembley Arena">Wembley Arena</a>, as well as many mid-sized venues, such as <a href="/wiki/Brixton_Academy" title="Brixton Academy">Brixton Academy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hammersmith_Apollo" title="Hammersmith Apollo">Hammersmith Apollo</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Shepherd%27s_Bush_Empire" title="Shepherd's Bush Empire">Shepherd's Bush Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-London's_Concerts_435-3"><a href="#cite_note-London's_Concerts-435">[427]</a></sup> Several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Music_festivals" title="Music festivals">music festivals</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Wireless_Festival" title="Wireless Festival">Wireless Festival</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lovebox_Festival" title="Lovebox Festival">Lovebox</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London" title="Hyde Park, London">Hyde Park</a>'s <a href="/wiki/British_Summer_Time_(concerts)" title="British Summer Time (concerts)">British Summer Time</a>, are held in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[477]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city is home to the original <a href="/wiki/Hard_Rock_Cafe" title="Hard Rock Cafe">Hard Rock Cafe</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios" title="Abbey Road Studios">Abbey Road Studios</a>, where <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> recorded many of their hits. In the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, musicians and groups like <a href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pink_Floyd" title="Pink Floyd">Pink Floyd</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Bowie" title="David Bowie">David Bowie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">Queen</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Kinks" title="The Kinks">The Kinks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cliff_Richard" title="Cliff Richard">Cliff Richard</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Who" title="The Who">The Who</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Clapton" title="Eric Clapton">Eric Clapton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Led_Zeppelin" title="Led Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron_Maiden" title="Iron Maiden">Iron Maiden</a>, <a href="/wiki/T._Rex_(band)" title="T. Rex (band)">T. Rex</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fleetwood_Mac" title="Fleetwood Mac">Fleetwood Mac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Costello" title="Elvis Costello">Elvis Costello</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dire_Straits" title="Dire Straits">Dire Straits</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cat_Stevens" title="Cat Stevens">Cat Stevens</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Police" title="The Police">The Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Cure" title="The Cure">The Cure</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madness_(band)" title="Madness (band)">Madness</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_Club" title="Culture Club">Culture Club</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dusty_Springfield" title="Dusty Springfield">Dusty Springfield</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phil_Collins" title="Phil Collins">Phil Collins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rod_Stewart" title="Rod Stewart">Rod Stewart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Status_Quo_(band)" title="Status Quo (band)">Status Quo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sade_(band)" title="Sade (band)">Sade</a>, derived their sound from the streets and rhythms of London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top40_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-Top40-486">[478]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[479]</a></sup>
</p><p>London was instrumental in the development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punk_music" title="Punk music">punk music</a>, with figures such as the <a href="/wiki/Sex_Pistols" title="Sex Pistols">Sex Pistols</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Clash" title="The Clash">The Clash</a> and fashion designer <a href="/wiki/Vivienne_Westwood" title="Vivienne Westwood">Vivienne Westwood</a> all based in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[481]</a></sup> Other artists to emerge from the London music scene include <a href="/wiki/George_Michael" title="George Michael">George Michael</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kate_Bush" title="Kate Bush">Kate Bush</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seal_(musician)" title="Seal (musician)">Seal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pet_Shop_Boys" title="Pet Shop Boys">Pet Shop Boys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siouxsie_and_the_Banshees" title="Siouxsie and the Banshees">Siouxsie and the Banshees</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bush_(British_band)" title="Bush (British band)">Bush</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Spice_Girls" title="Spice Girls">Spice Girls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jamiroquai" title="Jamiroquai">Jamiroquai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blur_(band)" title="Blur (band)">Blur</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Prodigy" title="The Prodigy">The Prodigy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gorillaz" title="Gorillaz">Gorillaz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mumford_%26_Sons" title="Mumford &amp; Sons">Mumford &amp; Sons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coldplay" title="Coldplay">Coldplay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amy_Winehouse" title="Amy Winehouse">Amy Winehouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adele" title="Adele">Adele</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sam_Smith_(singer)" title="Sam Smith (singer)">Sam Smith</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ed_Sheeran" title="Ed Sheeran">Ed Sheeran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ellie_Goulding" title="Ellie Goulding">Ellie Goulding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dua_Lipa" title="Dua Lipa">Dua Lipa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Florence_and_the_Machine" title="Florence and the Machine">Florence and the Machine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scene_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scene-490">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[483]</a></sup> Artists from London with a Caribbean influence include <a href="/wiki/Hot_Chocolate_(band)" title="Hot Chocolate (band)">Hot Chocolate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Ocean" title="Billy Ocean">Billy Ocean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soul_II_Soul" title="Soul II Soul">Soul II Soul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eddy_Grant" title="Eddy Grant">Eddy Grant</a>, with the latter fusing <a href="/wiki/Reggae" title="Reggae">reggae</a>, soul and samba with rock and pop.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[484]</a></sup> London is also a centre for urban music. In particular the genres <a href="/wiki/UK_garage" title="UK garage">UK garage</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drum_and_bass" title="Drum and bass">drum and bass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dubstep" title="Dubstep">dubstep</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grime_(music)" title="Grime (music)">grime</a> evolved in the city from the foreign genres of <a href="/wiki/House_music" title="House music">house</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip hop</a>, and reggae, alongside local <a href="/wiki/Drum_and_bass" title="Drum and bass">drum and bass</a>. Music station <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_1Xtra" title="BBC Radio 1Xtra">BBC Radio 1Xtra</a> was set up to support the rise of local <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urban_contemporary" title="Urban contemporary">urban contemporary</a> music both in London and in the rest of the United Kingdom. The <a href="/wiki/British_Phonographic_Industry" title="British Phonographic Industry">British Phonographic Industry</a>'s annual popular music awards, the <a href="/wiki/Brit_Awards" title="Brit Awards">Brit Awards</a>, are held in London, usually in February.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[485]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Recreation">Recreation</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks_and_open_spaces">Parks and open spaces</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Parks_and_open_spaces_in_London" title="Parks and open spaces in London">Parks and open spaces in London</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Parks_of_London" title="Royal Parks of London">Royal Parks of London</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Sites_of_Special_Scientific_Interest_in_Greater_London" title="List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Greater London">List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Greater London</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_local_nature_reserves_in_Greater_London" title="List of local nature reserves in Greater London">List of local nature reserves in Greater London</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg/220px-Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg/330px-Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg/440px-Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hyde_Park_London_from_the_air.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London" title="Hyde Park, London">Hyde Park</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Kensington_Gardens" title="Kensington Gardens">Kensington Gardens</a> in foreground) has been a popular public space since it opened in 1637</div></div></div>
<p>A 2013 report by the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation" title="City of London Corporation">City of London Corporation</a> said that London is the "greenest city" in Europe with 14,164 hectares (35,000 acres) of public parks, woodlands and gardens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[486]</a></sup> The largest parks in the <a href="/wiki/Central_London" title="Central London">central area of London</a> are three of the eight <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Parks_of_London" title="Royal Parks of London">Royal Parks</a>, namely <a href="/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London" title="Hyde Park, London">Hyde Park</a> and its neighbour <a href="/wiki/Kensington_Gardens" title="Kensington Gardens">Kensington Gardens</a> in the west, and <a href="/wiki/Regent%27s_Park" title="Regent's Park">Regent's Park</a> to the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_080_495-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_080-495">[487]</a></sup> Hyde Park in particular is popular for <a href="#Sport">sports</a> and sometimes hosts open-air concerts. Regent's Park contains <a href="/wiki/London_Zoo" title="London Zoo">London Zoo</a>, the world's oldest scientific zoo, and is near <a href="/wiki/Madame_Tussauds" title="Madame Tussauds">Madame Tussauds</a> Wax Museum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_081_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_081-496">[488]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_082_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_082-497">[489]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Primrose_Hill" title="Primrose Hill">Primrose Hill</a>, immediately to the north of Regent's Park, at 256 feet (78 m)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[490]</a></sup> is a popular spot from which to view the city skyline.
</p><p>Close to Hyde Park are smaller Royal Parks, <a href="/wiki/Green_Park" title="Green Park">Green Park</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._James%27s_Park" title="St. James's Park">St. James's Park</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_083_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_083-499">[491]</a></sup> A number of large parks lie outside the city centre, including <a href="/wiki/Hampstead_Heath" title="Hampstead Heath">Hampstead Heath</a> and the remaining Royal Parks of <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Park" title="Greenwich Park">Greenwich Park</a> to the southeast<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_170_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_170-500">[492]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Bushy_Park" title="Bushy Park">Bushy Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Richmond_Park" title="Richmond Park">Richmond Park</a> (the largest) to the southwest,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_084_501-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_084-501">[493]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_085_502-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_085-502">[494]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Court_Park" title="Hampton Court Park">Hampton Court Park</a> is also a royal park, but, because it contains a palace, it is administered by the <a href="/wiki/Historic_Royal_Palaces" title="Historic Royal Palaces">Historic Royal Palaces</a>, unlike the eight <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Parks_of_London" title="Royal Parks of London">Royal Parks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[495]</a></sup>
</p><p>Close to Richmond Park is <a href="/wiki/Kew_Gardens" title="Kew Gardens">Kew Gardens</a>, which has the world's largest collection of living plants. In 2003, the gardens were put on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Educational,_Scientific_and_Cultural_Organization" title="United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization">UNESCO</a> list of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of World Heritage Sites of the United Kingdom">World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[496]</a></sup> There are also parks administered by London's borough Councils, including <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Park,_London" title="Victoria Park, London">Victoria Park</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_End" title="East End">East End</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battersea_Park" title="Battersea Park">Battersea Park</a> in the centre. Some more informal, semi-natural open spaces also exist, including the 320-hectare (790-acre) <a href="/wiki/Hampstead_Heath" title="Hampstead Heath">Hampstead Heath</a> of <a href="/wiki/North_London" title="North London">North London</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[497]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Epping_Forest" title="Epping Forest">Epping Forest</a>, which covers 2,476 hectares (6,118 acres)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[498]</a></sup> in the east. Both are controlled by the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation" title="City of London Corporation">City of London Corporation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[499]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[500]</a></sup> Hampstead Heath incorporates <a href="/wiki/Kenwood_House" title="Kenwood House">Kenwood House</a>, a former <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stately_home" title="Stately home">stately home</a> and a popular location in the summer months when classical musical concerts are held by the lake, attracting thousands of people every weekend to enjoy the music, scenery and fireworks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_086_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_086-509">[501]</a></sup> Epping Forest is a popular venue for various outdoor activities, including mountain biking, walking, horse riding, golf, angling, and orienteering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[502]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Walking">Walking</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Horse_Ride,_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Horse_Ride%2C_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg/220px-Horse_Ride%2C_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Horse_Ride%2C_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg/330px-Horse_Ride%2C_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Horse_Ride%2C_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg/440px-Horse_Ride%2C_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Horse_Ride,_Wimbledon_Common_-_geograph.org.uk_-_692221.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Horse Ride is a <a href="/wiki/Tree_tunnel" title="Tree tunnel">tree tunnel</a> (route overhung by trees) on the western side of <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon_Common" title="Wimbledon Common">Wimbledon Common</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Walking_in_London" title="Walking in London">Walking is a popular recreational activity in London</a>. Areas that provide for walks include <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon_Common" title="Wimbledon Common">Wimbledon Common</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epping_Forest" title="Epping Forest">Epping Forest</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Court_Park" title="Hampton Court Park">Hampton Court Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hampstead_Heath" title="Hampstead Heath">Hampstead Heath</a>, the eight <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Parks" title="Royal Parks">Royal Parks</a>, canals and disused railway tracks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-511">[503]</a></sup> Access to canals and rivers has improved recently, including the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Thames_Path" title="Thames Path">Thames Path</a>, some 28 miles (45 km) of which is within <a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">Greater London</a>, and The <a href="/wiki/Wandle_Trail" title="Wandle Trail">Wandle Trail</a>; this runs 12 miles (19 km) through <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South London</a> along the <a href="/wiki/River_Wandle" title="River Wandle">River Wandle</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Tributaries_of_the_River_Thames" title="Tributaries of the River Thames">tributary of the River Thames</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[504]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Long-distance_path" title="Long-distance path">long-distance paths</a>, linking green spaces, have also been created, including the <a href="/wiki/Capital_Ring" title="Capital Ring">Capital Ring</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Green_Chain_Walk" title="Green Chain Walk">Green Chain Walk</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Outer_Orbital_Path" title="London Outer Orbital Path">London Outer Orbital Path</a> ("Loop"), <a href="/wiki/Jubilee_Walkway" title="Jubilee Walkway">Jubilee Walkway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lea_Valley_Walk" title="Lea Valley Walk">Lea Valley Walk</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Diana,_Princess_of_Wales_Memorial_Walk" title="Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Walk">Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Walk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_511-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-511">[503]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_London" title="Sport in London">Sport in London</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:219px;max-width:219px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1885" data-file-width="2926" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg/215px-Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg/323px-Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg/430px-Wembley_Stadium_interior.jpg 2x" width="215"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium" title="Wembley Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>, home of the England <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">men</a> and <a href="/wiki/England_women%27s_national_football_team" title="England women's national football team">women's football team</a> and the <a href="/wiki/FA_Cup_Final" title="FA Cup Final">FA Cup Final</a>, has a seating capacity of 90,000. It is the UK's biggest stadium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[505]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="280" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="75" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg/215px-Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg/323px-Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg/430px-Centre_Court_Wimbledon_1.jpg 2x" width="215"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Centre_Court" title="Centre Court">Centre Court</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a>. Held every June and July, Wimbledon is the oldest tennis tournament in the world, and the only major played on grass.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="577" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg/215px-Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg/323px-Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg/430px-Twickenham_stadium_-_Cup_finals_day_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2966637.jpg 2x" width="215"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Twickenham_Stadium" title="Twickenham Stadium">Twickenham</a>, home of the <a href="/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team" title="England national rugby union team">England national rugby union team</a>, has a capacity of 82,000 seats.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>London has hosted the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympics</a> three times: in <a href="/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics" title="1908 Summer Olympics">1908</a>, <a href="/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics" title="1948 Summer Olympics">1948</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_173_514-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_173-514">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_174_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_174-515">[507]</a></sup> making it the first city to host the modern Games three times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IOC_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-IOC-39">[35]</a></sup> The city was also the host of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Games" title="Commonwealth Games">British Empire Games</a> in <a href="/wiki/1934_British_Empire_Games" title="1934 British Empire Games">1934</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_175_516-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_175-516">[508]</a></sup> In 2017, London hosted the <a href="/wiki/2017_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2017 World Championships in Athletics">World Championships in Athletics</a> for the first time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[509]</a></sup>
</p><p>London's <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_United_Kingdom#Popularity" title="Sport in the United Kingdom">most popular sport</a> is <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>, and it has seven clubs in the <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">Premier League</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_Premier_League" title="2022–23 Premier League">2022–23 season</a>: <a href="/wiki/Arsenal_F.C." title="Arsenal F.C.">Arsenal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brentford_F.C." title="Brentford F.C.">Brentford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chelsea_F.C." title="Chelsea F.C.">Chelsea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crystal_Palace_F.C." title="Crystal Palace F.C.">Crystal Palace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fulham_F.C." title="Fulham F.C.">Fulham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C." title="Tottenham Hotspur F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>, and <a href="/wiki/West_Ham_United_F.C." title="West Ham United F.C.">West Ham United</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_176_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_176-518">[510]</a></sup> Other professional men's teams in London are <a href="/wiki/AFC_Wimbledon" title="AFC Wimbledon">AFC Wimbledon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barnet_F.C." title="Barnet F.C.">Barnet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bromley_F.C." title="Bromley F.C.">Bromley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charlton_Athletic_F.C." title="Charlton Athletic F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dagenham_%26_Redbridge_F.C." title="Dagenham &amp; Redbridge F.C.">Dagenham &amp; Redbridge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leyton_Orient_F.C." title="Leyton Orient F.C.">Leyton Orient</a>, <a href="/wiki/Millwall_F.C." title="Millwall F.C.">Millwall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queens_Park_Rangers_F.C." title="Queens Park Rangers F.C.">Queens Park Rangers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sutton_United_F.C." title="Sutton United F.C.">Sutton United</a>. Four London-based teams are in the <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Super_League" title="Women's Super League">Women's Super League</a>: <a href="/wiki/Arsenal_W.F.C." title="Arsenal W.F.C.">Arsenal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chelsea_F.C._Women" title="Chelsea F.C. Women">Chelsea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C._Women" title="Tottenham Hotspur F.C. Women">Tottenham</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Ham_United_F.C._Women" title="West Ham United F.C. Women">West Ham United</a>.
</p><p>From 1924, the original <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_(1923)" title="Wembley Stadium (1923)">Wembley Stadium</a> was the home of the <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">English national football team</a>. It hosted the <a href="/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="1966 FIFA World Cup Final">1966 FIFA World Cup Final</a>, with England defeating West Germany, and served as the venue for the <a href="/wiki/FA_Cup_Final" title="FA Cup Final">FA Cup Final</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">rugby league</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Challenge_Cup" title="Challenge Cup">Challenge Cup</a> final.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_178_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_178-519">[511]</a></sup> The new <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium" title="Wembley Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a> serves the same purposes and has a capacity of 90,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wembley_Stadium_Facts_and_Figures_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wembley_Stadium_Facts_and_Figures-520">[512]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/England_women%27s_national_football_team" title="England women's national football team">women's team</a> defeated Germany at Wembley to win <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Women%27s_Euro_2022" title="UEFA Women's Euro 2022">Euro 2022</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[513]</a></sup>
</p><p>Three <a href="/wiki/Premiership_Rugby" title="Premiership Rugby">Premiership Rugby</a> union teams are based in London, <a href="/wiki/Harlequin_F.C." title="Harlequin F.C.">Harlequins</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Irish" title="London Irish">London Irish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saracens_F.C." title="Saracens F.C.">Saracens</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_177_522-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_177-522">[514]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ealing_Trailfinders_Rugby_Club" title="Ealing Trailfinders Rugby Club">Ealing Trailfinders</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Scottish_F.C." title="London Scottish F.C.">London Sottish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Richmond_F.C." title="Richmond F.C.">Richmond</a> play in the <a href="/wiki/RFU_Championship" title="RFU Championship">RFU Championship</a>; other rugby union clubs in the city include Scottish, <a href="/wiki/Rosslyn_Park_F.C." title="Rosslyn Park F.C.">Rosslyn Park F.C.</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Westcombe_Park_R.F.C." title="Westcombe Park R.F.C.">Westcombe Park R.F.C.</a> and <a href="/wiki/Blackheath_F.C." title="Blackheath F.C.">Blackheath F.C.</a> <a href="/wiki/Twickenham_Stadium" title="Twickenham Stadium">Twickenham Stadium</a> in south-west London hosts home matches for the <a href="/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team" title="England national rugby union team">England national rugby union team</a> and has a capacity of 82,000 now that the new south stand has been completed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-musiccap_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-musiccap-523">[515]</a></sup>
</p><p>While <a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">rugby league</a> is more popular in the north of England, there are two professional rugby league clubs in London – the <a href="/wiki/London_Broncos" title="London Broncos">London Broncos</a> in the second-tier <a href="/wiki/RFL_Championship" title="RFL Championship">RFL Championship</a>, who play at the <a href="/wiki/Trailfinders_Sports_Ground" title="Trailfinders Sports Ground">Trailfinders Sports Ground</a> in <a href="/wiki/West_Ealing" title="West Ealing">West Ealing</a>, and the third-tier <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/League_1_(rugby_league)" title="League 1 (rugby league)">League 1</a> team, the <a href="/wiki/London_Skolars" title="London Skolars">London Skolars</a> from <a href="/wiki/Wood_Green" title="Wood Green">Wood Green</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Haringey" title="London Borough of Haringey">Haringey</a>.
</p><p>One of London's best-known annual sports competitions is the <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon_Championships" title="Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon Tennis Championships</a>, held at the <a href="/wiki/All_England_Lawn_Tennis_and_Croquet_Club" title="All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club">All England Club</a> in the south-western suburb of <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon,_London" title="Wimbledon, London">Wimbledon</a> since 1877.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_181_524-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_181-524">[516]</a></sup> Played in late June to early July, it is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and widely considered the most prestigious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[517]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[518]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[519]</a></sup> Founded in London in 1881, <a href="/wiki/Slazenger" title="Slazenger">Slazenger</a> has provided tennis balls for Wimbledon since 1902, the oldest sponsorship in sport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[520]</a></sup>
</p><p>London has two <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test cricket</a> grounds, <a href="/wiki/Lord%27s" title="Lord's">Lord's</a> (home of <a href="/wiki/Middlesex_County_Cricket_Club" title="Middlesex County Cricket Club">Middlesex C.C.C.</a>) in <a href="/wiki/St_John%27s_Wood" title="St John's Wood">St John's Wood</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_179_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_179-529">[521]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/The_Oval" title="The Oval">the Oval</a> (home of <a href="/wiki/Surrey_County_Cricket_Club" title="Surrey County Cricket Club">Surrey C.C.C.</a>) in <a href="/wiki/Kennington" title="Kennington">Kennington</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_180_530-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_180-530">[522]</a></sup> Lord's has hosted four finals of the <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cup</a> and is known as the <i>Home of Cricket</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[523]</a></sup> Other key events are the annual mass-participation <a href="/wiki/London_Marathon" title="London Marathon">London Marathon</a>, in which some 35,000 runners attempt a 26.2-mile (42.2 km) course around the city,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_182_532-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_182-532">[524]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_Boat_Race" title="University Boat Race">University Boat Race</a> on the Thames from <a href="/wiki/Putney" title="Putney">Putney</a> to <a href="/wiki/Mortlake" title="Mortlake">Mortlake</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-london_183_533-0"><a href="#cite_note-london_183-533">[525]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_people">Notable people</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_people_from_London" title="List of people from London">List of people from London</a></div>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1093669538">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalborder>ul{padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint plainlist portalbox portalborder tright" role="navigation">
